RATING: 6
Rated a 3 after my first play. 3p, took nearly an hour, we all went for the same 'mass cards, get nobles' strat and were relieved when the game ended. 

Decided it needed another shot and have put a few hours into Prestige and now the official app. Upgraded to a 6. I think it's too abstract to be a good gateway for most, but as I find myself thinking more about how chips circulate, reserving cards, when/how to go for the higher tier cards right off the bat... I'm finding it a bit more interesting than I previously thought. 

In terms of the physical game I still think I'd keep it to 3p max, I expect it to be a bit too slow and chaotic at 4p.

RATING: 9
36+ plays / 2,3,4 players.

LIKE: Great engine building, feels like it's stripped to the core, but it works. Great artwork, good depth, fast game.
DISLIKE: Some randomness in the cards that come out. Level 3 cards don't move as much (2 player), so strategy is a little static with those cards. small level of luck involved.
OVERALL: Very fun. A classic. I've seen different strategies prevail: use your reserves to block players, make a rush for the 2 or 3 level cards, Chip hoarding.

RATING: 9
Certainly an approachable incredibly produced game. Game play is very easy to understand: take chips or buy cards (or perhaps reserve a card). But there is a joy derived from buying cards, a tension in wondering if your fellow players will interfere (knowingly? unknowingly?), and a rush when your combination of cards lets you buy the 'expensive' things. It's very brisk - there's a snowball effect at the end which spins everyone headlong inside 40 minutes (or even less). I put it as a very original gateway game - nothing like Ticket to Ride or Carcassonne, but equal in stature and family fun.

RATING: 6
*Rating based on one play.

Splendor is the definition of a game with a pasted-on theme.  The game is simple and has decent decision points, but also a fairly high degree of luck.  It's short enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome, so it has that going for it.  As a light filler goes, you could do worse.

Having said that, I would not pay the $40 MSRP for this game.  The game has clay chips that are very nice, but there aren't that many (40), and the rest of the game is some cards and a handful of chipboard tiles.  There are quite a few unique illustrations on the cards, which probably contributed to the cost, but not all 90 cards have their own illustration.  I would put this at a $30 value.  On top of that, the box has an excessive amount of unused space (probably to justify the price of the game), making it take up far more room than I would like for a light filler.  It takes up more space on the shelf and in the game bag than it deserves.

RATING: 7.5
Ever wondered what it'd feel like to be debeers? I am always up for a game of splendor. It is a well designed game involving a little luck but mostly skill. You spend your rounds either acquiring gems or using them to purchase mines that auto produce buying power and sometimes have victory points. You are attempting to obtain enough buying power to purchase enough mines to gain enough victory points to win. If you purchase the right configurations, you also attract nobles worth points and speed along your victory. This game was second place in the spiel to camel up and I believe the first game by space Cowboys. Thankfully not their last.

RATING: 7
When I approached Splendor for the first time, it had been the new hotness already for quite a while. So maybe I had too high expectations, but I was not particularly impressed by it... even if I liked it quite a bit.

Splendor is for sure gorgeous looking with its artwork and those nice chunky poker chips. The game-play instead is very straight-forward and it's all about optimization. You have to build an engine and time your actions really well if you want to come out on top. This makes Splendor a very interesting puzzle. My main complaint with the game is that most of your turns are not really that exciting. You just take some poker chips and hope no one else buys the card you want. That's the same problem I have with Ticket to Ride. Spendor however is faster and, especially, more interesting for me as a mental exercise and therefore I like it a lot more than TtR.

I may not have found the mind blowing game everyone was raving about, but I found a pretty good game with some solid concepts and an interesting challenge. It's a very nice game. Just I wouldn't consider purchasing it. I enjoy it but I think I'll be fine using someone else's copy.

RATING: 7
This is a typical engine building game, where you have to amass certain number of so called gems in order to buy cards, which in turn provide permanent production of gems, which you will be able to procure even more cards. Some cards, usually which are expensive (lot of gems needed) have score values. And the player who achieves at first 16 points ends the game. It is a straight forward engine building game, fast paced and easy to learn.

RATING: 8.5
Probably my most played game in my collection. So easy to pull out and surprisingly deep.

I entirely do NOT understand complaints of multiplayer solitaire on this game. All player states are completely visible and very easy to parse at a glance.  You can guess opponent strategy fairly seamlessly and move in to block by reserving something they want or see they will beat you to a card and move toward another one.

The only negative on this game is that giving away your strategies can be so damaging to your play that we find ourselves closely guarding our plans, making this a fairly quiet game of people staring at the table and quietly making their moves.  This type of behavior is NOT multiplayer solitaire, quite the reverse, but I can see that this is not what some are looking for in a game.

RATING: 5
I really wanted to like this game a lot. Of course ultimately, this game is seriously very light. However several factors keep it from being "good". Number one and foremost is the fact that the game ends at 15 points. It feels way too soon for most of the strategies in the game, as you feel like it's barely half over by that point. Also the component quality is really poor. Really, poker chips for gems when you can buy actual acrylic gem pieces much cheaper? Really guys? And a box that's 4 times larger than the components all assembled together. The game is also very swingy based on what nobles are in play and when certain gems come up. If the deck(s) clump together, it throws off the entire game's balance forever which I see as a fatal flaw. Otherwise the game has a ton of potential and I can be talked into playing it.

RATING: 4.5
I've played this now three or four times and, each time, I find myself simply not caring. Star Realms is just as easy to teach, just as portable, and is basically the same game with a little bit of added flavor and more player interaction. Minus all that, and you're just playing Klondike. I'd gladly play Klondike by myself, but I can't think of any reason to play it in a variant where you have to wait for other people to play a move before you're allowed to play your next move.

I think that my other issue with the game is that I would like it to be an engine building game. I want to create something that's able to churn out gems and power my way through whatever might come. It presents itself like it should be that sort of game. But at the official game length (and, granted, I don't play Star Realms to its official hit point count), winning in Splendor seems to be more of a puzzle rather than a build. It's purely down to looking at the highest valued card on the table when the game starts and finding the shortest path to it.

I like puzzle games. I've exhausted Simon Tatham's Portable Puzzle Collection. But those are solitary games. Splendor is also a solitary game, where other players act as a randomizing element to obscure the path to the target. And played solitary, on a cell phone, I might become very good at the puzzle and be able to dominate in live play, but meh.

Star Realms doesn't have that same, definable target, the high card. There is some flavor to the different strategies one can take to defeat his opponent. When you lose, you have to figure out what tricks your opponent pulled, and see if you can pull it off as well, or find a way to defeat it. While subtle, there is some jostling around in there. In Splendor, there is only one real strategy: The shortest path. And once you've gotten good at that, success against your opponents becomes luck of the draw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Purchased after developing an affection for Jaipur, and on the grounds of it being a minimalist distillation of the engine building style. 

After a single play, I found it a touch lack luster with two. The play experience felt relatively dry. Unlike Jaipur, it doesn't feel like the game space is tight enough for two; the game would have more tension if you were vying over a tighter selection of cards. As it stands now, it is unlikely you'll both value the same card, so play becomes little more than a race to grab to see who can optimize their chosen path quickest. 

Will try it again. Perhaps my provisional rating will increase. 

For what it is worth, my partner enjoyed the experience faaaaar more, and we enjoyed its fast playtime as well. 

Oct. 22nd update: Yes, I raised the score from 5 to 6.5. It is a fun, very thinky game. Sadly, the ending is abrupt and anticlimactic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great pieces, particularly the poker chips that are really nice to manipulate ! Splendor is a relatively short game with easy to learn mechanics.

Basically, you can take resources - 3 different ones or two of the same type - or buy a card which'll give you one virtual resource each turn. Doing so,you score victory points and begin to build your engine to buy cards granting more points, as they are more expensive resource-wise to get...

There are also noble guests to invite to your house, those VIPs only granting 3 victory points each. They'll come to visit you if you manage to get a certain number of cards giving you particular resources... Whenever a player reaches 15 points, the other players have one more turn to play. The player with the most victory points total wins the game.

The game is fluid, quick, tensed, but feels really different if you play with 2 or 4 players, the former being less chaotic than the later. I'll never turnaway from a Splendor game.

RATING: 6
This game is a good puzzle. It often escalates extremely quickly and I tend to lose to my wife almost every time as a result. Balancing noble tiles, high-scoring prestige cards, and your humming gem engine is tough! It's a light game, but there is also depth available for typically heavier gamers. At two players it's a very strategic game... while at three and (especially) four players it becomes highly tactical. It's enjoyable regardless!

My favorite aspect is the amazing quality and weight of the gem chips. I want to do a Scrooge McDuck swan dive into a pile of those chips. I want them in every game.

RATING: 6.1
This is not a bad game, but...I am not as enamored with it as others seem to be.  I feel like luck can play quite a bit of a role.  You need personage tiles to win, but snagging the right cards to acquire them can prove to be a tricky endeavor if the right ones come out at the wrong time (i.e. before you even have an opportunity to acquire them).

Unfortunately, that someone else inevitably thinks of at least one instance where they were screwed by the luck of the draw (which, of course, could have made all of the difference).

RATING: 9
This is one of the most well thought out games to be produced in some time. Sure, it isn't mind-blowingly complex or thought=provoking. You collect resources via some poker-style chips and use them to purchase cards from a central display. Those cards add to a permanent set of resources you control that aid in purchasing more expensive cards from the central display again. It is simple but brings out a complex game that moves along at a steady pace and never wears out its welcome. This game should win the Spiel award it has been nominated for. We don't think there is another game out there that plays as smooth and as seamlessly as this one but still brings out so much fun.

RATING: 7
Beautiful components, simple rules, straightforward gameplay, some tactics, Splendor is a wonderful introductory/filler game.  Be the first person to accrue 15 victory points by either gaining gems/cards or nobles worth victory points and win the game!  It's also VERY easy to teach, to learn, and to play!  Very little downtime!

Chip collecting and engine-building combine to drive the game forward rapidly -- if everyone knows the rules, it's about 30 minutes per game!

A bit dull with two, Splendor ramps well to three and four players.  Be warned:  there is some luck involved in the game.

Not much to speak of theme-wise.

RATING: 6.8
Swift playing, lovely artwork, solid components. Has more depth and more viable strategies than is apparent after a first play, depending in large part (far more than you'd expect) on the specific mix of nobles for the game. Very tactical, with an interesting balance point which determines the relative importance of buying cards for your engine, versus buying cards purely for points.

In the end, the game doesn't really excite, though, and I've grown pretty weary of it. There's just not enough of a _game_ there.

RATING: 7
Splendor is a very engaging, very quick, economic-engine game that provides a moderate amount of brain-burn. It's a game that I really enjoy playing and something that has received nothing but positive remarks from other gamers. That being said, the speed/engaging-feel might be making the game feel more deep than it actually is. Don't get me wrong, your decisions matter in this game and you need to focus on the board and other players. But after 9-plays, I'm starting to feel how the random elements can impact the game.

But being such a quick game, it is essentially a filler... and has a remarkable number of meaningful decisions for that. Component quality is amazing but I am actually starting to dislike the heavy-weight poker chips; if you carry your game around, they tend to fly everywhere. Perhaps lighter wooden chips would have been a better decision.

RATING: 9
An excellent game, the first I've played where you take the role of a master jeweller. It's a familiar Dominion-esque setup, which is made unique by the finite resources available to the players at any one time, in the form of jewel tokens. These are of a high quality by the way, resembling properly weighted poker chips, and the cards are sturdy and glossy.

A good price makes this very difficult to not recommend to anyone and everyone.

RATING: 7

Cards are nice, and chips are good quality, but to me a bit out of place.  The chips are kind of poker type, and to me they look a bit strange when playing, but this is totally personal.  I have played with big plastic gems instead of the chips, and it looks definitely better (well done, Jokin!).

RATING: 7
Splendor is the gamer's idea of a filler: it is quick, abstract but filled with some meaningful decisions.
It is a set collection game, with some indirect confrontation: players can reserve a card if they see you're going to take it, and hinder your progression.
There is some luck involved, as new cards turned could benefit the next player, but it's definitely tolerable in such a fast paced game.
Final mention goes to components: cards are sturdy and beautifully illustrated, chips are wonderfully weighty, and the box has a great insert to keep everything finely organized.
Could've won the SdJ, but barely missed it!

RATING: 6
:d10-3:
Splendor had been off my radar for some time, as it didn't seem to offer anything of interest to me personally. After playing, I can see the appeal.

The resource system feels a bit like Magic's mana system, which makes you feel smart for proper sequencing. The economic snowball makes you feel like you are continually improving, even if other players are improving more efficiently. The character tiles give you a long-term goal to pursue, which provides an ever-so-subtle element of coopetition in the early-to-mid game.

That said, the decisions were not interesting enough for me to want to play again. If I did, I sense that it would be best with exactly 3 players.

RATING: 7
A solid game, a better designed game there has never been.  It really boils down the essence of quite a few other engine/take-that games into a really good little package.

That said, there are three itches this scratches:
1) Getting stuff that wins you the game
2) Screwing-over someone else who wants your stuff
3) Building some semblance of an engine

And I found myself thinking that Cargo Noir was actually pretty good at 1 & 2, and I feel like there's a huge thrill-fest in engine building that makes this either better or worse depending on your situation. 

I'm not much for being an engine guy, but over repeated plays, engine stuff is where it's at.

For all the design, and everything that's good about it...  still kind of 'meh' on all of it.   No 'wow' factor in it for me other than this - It would definitely be the first thing I reached for in the more advanced games.  Not that it's more advanced, but a lot of the theory is expanded in advanced games.  If you love the engine building stuff....hooo boy are there a lot of games to see.  If you hate the engine building stuff....well, lots of options.

On an aside, the iOS app...  go for bonus tiles every time, and you'll do no worse than 2nd place.

RATING: 9
At first, it feels like just some simple set collection game with Luck being the major factor to win the game. But after the second game, third game, and so on, I realized that it's definitely not luck. You need a good strategy, hand management, pay attention to your enemies' step and cover your own to win the game. And the more I play, the more I'm excited about this game. 

The first 2 or 3 games, we played splendor in silence. But as we keep playing, it's getting noisier as each of us trying to redirect and distract our own movement by pointing other player's movement possibilities, especially when they're approaching 15 pts. 

When that happened, we usually try to convince other players into joining our cause and collectively taking steps to hinder the winning player's step (and silently delivering our own steps to victory).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Poorly balanced and not developed.

Could be interesting with better numbers/balancing. The early cards are particularly egregious in that one player building a relatively expensive 2/1/1/1 [0 pts] card can flip over a 2/1 [0 pts] card for their opponents to enjoy.  Fifteen points does not feel like the right number; it is probably closest to correct in a 4-player game, but 2-player it should probably go to 20/21.  

All this is moot because the points themselves should be refactored to provide less swing-y endgame results (basically double all existing point cards and fine-tune for difficulty (e.g. all the early cards with points become 2 points and the more difficult 0 point cards become 1 point cards).

Couple all of this with stupidly interacting color schemes (study the cards of each suit relative to one another to discover what I mean), and...well, this game needed some more work.  A few quick changes could make this a much more enjoyable filler game, but as-is it feels like they just called it good enough to sell to the masses of idiots who will never investigate what they are playing.

RATING: 7.5
Fun game. Every play are normally tight with close scoring. Luck still play a part.

- Go for high value to gems cards
- Do not be fixated in nobles only
- Colour synergy helps (eg. blue and white)
- Concentrate on at most 2-3 colours 
- Try not to be in competition with more than 2 other players for the same colour
- Only block other players when it is beneficial to you
- Adapt gameplay according to aggressive nature of opponents (i.e., reserve an expensive card when almost half of the required gems are obtained)

RATING: 7.4
A easy to learn, easy to teach, strategy game that's difficulty is based by the players at the table. Play is fast as each turn you have three options; Take gems, reserve card, buy card(it could be considered four as "take gems" actually has two different ways.) Cards have victory points along with Noble tiles which are acquired if you have the right cards. When a player reaches 15 the game is in it's final round, allowing all players equal turns. Highest score wins.

Up until recently I thought this game was underrated and should be played more. It's simple, yet has teeth in the game play by blocking opponents plays. After a few plays this month it's been brought back down to earth. Much like Race for the Galaxy, this is probably best played at two player, but can be played at a higher player count. 

The problem is, a weaker player at the table can screw the balance of the game up. If they aren't blocking somebody at the table is going to be having their way. If you are lucky it's you and you win. Unlucky, well enjoy losing a game simply by seating arrangement. It's mightily frustrating to sit at a table and watch someone give somebody else the win as you are too polite or defeated to scream "FOR THE LOVE OF GOD STOP THEM!"

At two players, with evenly matched competition, it's a pretty fun. At more players... you better be really evenly matched.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pro's:

1) Great components and art style.
2) The game just feels very well designed, everything seems to just work really well, with the limit on the gems; creating the card tableau; then having to completely rework your strategy based on what another player does.

Con's:

1) The game is really simple, I feel like I've basically "experienced" it to its max potential even though logically I haven't.
2) It's so obviously designed to be streamlined and easy to grasp that it makes it way more dry then it should be. I love euro games and this somehow manages to feel more like a spreadsheet then most of the others I have played.

RATING: 6
Poker style tokens are the biggest magnet to the game ;) just kidding. Splendor is great. It doesn't have strong theme, box is too big and too pretty compared to what's inside. In the box You will find some cardboard tiles, cards and heavy tokens. It is so great to hold them in hand ;) It is a game of chip-collecting and card development. All of the cards you buy increase your wealth as they give you a permanent bonus in the future  buys. Some of the cards also give you prestige points. In order to win the game, you must reach 15 prestige points (I've changed it to 21 to make game last longer) before your opponents do.

- playing time (30-50 minutes)
- I know many people who don't like this game at all. They don't "feel it".
- After paying for this game You can feel ripped off when You open the box

STRONG RECOMMENDATION.

RATING: 6
30 plays:

Elegant, but a little dry compared to the clearer theme of 7 Wonders or the deck-building, play-chaining satisfaction of Dominion. Compared to those, it's almost like solitaire. Frustratingly little player interaction. Each turn presents a small, satisfying decision, though a close game presents analysis paralysis because there's so much useful information to consider. Doesn't seem like the gold coin feature was quite designed right -- it becomes much harder to be clear on which cards you can afford to buy, and at what cost.

Slightly easier than Istanbul and worth owning, but playing this with new gamers can lead to them going silent and just staring at the table instead of talking.  The app version can remove the need to own this, as it has quite good variable difficulties.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Splendor is a 20-30 minute engine building game in which players have only 3 options on their turns - take gems (the currency, in five colors), buy a card, or reserve a card and take a wild gem.  Cards give purchasing power in one of the 5 colors, and possibly points, and come in 3 levels, with higher levels costing more but worth more points.  

I like that Splendor strongly constrains the players options to essentially a single decision each turn.  This makes it very easy to teach.  Turns are short, and the game moves very quickly.  Players' engines build up quickly, which gives a noticeable feeling of progress.  The game usually finishes before it becomes tedious - my wife and I can play a 2 player game in 10-15 minutes.  It plays well from 2 to 4 players, although 4 players gets a little long, and can feel a little more random as well - which cards flip can decide the game.

However, I have found that with experienced players, Splendor can easily be decided by how the cards turn up.  This is a game with essentially a single mechanism and a single strategy (I may be exaggerating a little here, but this is clearly not a "many paths to victory" kind of game).  It is a quick, simple game - a filler - and will disappoint if it is expected to be more than a diversion.  

For me, this is my go-to filler game.  It is great for playing with those with AP, and with non-gamers.  At the price, I consider it an excellent buy, worthy of being in most collections, the exception being "serious" gamers who never play light games with non-gamers.

:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Good, simple, lightweight racing engine-building set collection game.
++ Good replayability from the different Noble cards and how the cards show up, so you must always think how to be the most efficient possible.
++ Super easy to teach, fast to set-up and fast to play.


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- Although there is some variability which could lead to a good replayability, it quickly become repetitive and thus, less and less fun to play.
-- It is too light for me (and it's really feel lighter than the BGG weight of 1.8 as of writing this).
-- It's definitely a small game package in a too large box.

RATING: 8
I really enjoy Splendor, as I've always enjoyed engine building games, and this one does it very simply and very well.  Basically, players are acquiring and spending colored chips in order to obtain cards.  All of the cards you acquire will give you a permanent chip of a color to spend toward future cards, and some cards also give you points.  First to 15 points wins.

The game strikes a nice balance of needing to build your engine, but also needing to race for points at the same time.  The cheap cards in the game allow you to build that engine more rapidly, but the expensive cards are the ones that also give you points.  So, a balance has to be struck.

Splendor is a great example of a game that is fun for gamers, yet super accessible for non-gamers, as the game can be taught in about a minute.  But, while the rules are simple, the decisions are not always so straight forward.

The only drawback with this game is the theme, which makes it seem as if they didn't even try to think of something reasonable.  Players could have been fighters recruiting heroes to slay monsters, CEOs assembling a work force to finish jobs, star travelers assembling a star fleet to complete missions, or any number of fun themes.  Instead, you get a generic renaissance theme that is really poorly done even as renaissance themes go, and the graphic design is quite uninspired to top it off.  It's really a shame, since the yawn inducing theme and art work may turn people off to what is a really fun game, especially when it comes to the non-gamer crowd which will easily be able to pick up on this game.

None the less, despite the missed opportunity for a good theme that could have added to the fun of playing, Splendor is a great, simple, mechanically fun game that I'd likely never turn down a game of.  Good stuff!

RATING: 7
Based on 1 play with 4 players:

This is a compelling, solidly designed system. The turns are quick and decisions are interesting. It's just not the sort of game I would play twice in a night.

It's not that Splendor does anything wrong. It just lacks some kind of hook for me. It is a game that is all about Scoring Points. I enjoy a great deal of these kinds of games, but generally they have either one killer mechanic going for them (even No Thanks, possibly the simplest game ever made, has a more tough and juicy mechanical hook) OR have a sense of progression and accomplishment - games where you're building something you can enjoy on an emotional/aesthetic level.

This game lacks both, and so is a game I would not turn down if offered, but will never be one of my great gaming loves.

Update: It is worth pointing out though that there REALLY aren't any other solidly designed economic games that play in this timeframe, so if you've got your heart set on a quick economic game this is IT. And this is still one of the meatiest games you can get in 20 minutes in general so if you don't already have something quick ' meaty (your Biblioses, your Eight-Minute Empires) this'll definitely fit the bill.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Having played it three times the first day I got it and four times the next day, which is highly unusual for me, I definitely understand why Splendor has been nominated for Spiel des Jahres! It’s such a good, light family game with a decent amount of strategy. People who say that there isn’t much strategy don’t understand the deeper layers in this game! You can block your opponents and at the start of the game you need to have a plan in order to get at least one of the bonus cards (which is a great feature of the game by the way), otherwise it’s going to be difficult to win.

The simplicity of the gameplay is what makes the game shine: you can do one action on your turn out of four possible actions which are extremely basic and easy to understand. Basically you collect gems to build cards which give you points and a discount on future cards. The first player to 15 (sort of) wins the game; the round is played to the end, but it usually doesn’t matter, though most games seem to be somewhat tight. The game starts out fairly slowly with players grabbing chips, but as you get more cards you also get bigger discounts, so the game speeds up and I think it ends exactly when it should after about half an hour. It’s not exactly a snow-balling effect as the more expensive cards are, well, expensive, so even though you get a discount you still need to pay a lot of chips. But some points give you 4 or 5 points, so the game can end suddenly and you can surprise your opponents - although everything is open information, so they can still try to block you from getting the cards you want. And this is actually a big part of the game, especially in a 2p-game as you really need to watch out for what your opponent can do. One of my plays against my wife was really awesome as we both played extremely well and blocked/reserved the cards the other player needed.

The components are nice, but the box is oversized which I hate due to limited shelf space. My siblings don’t dislike this game which is something that says a lot… Sure, it’s not a heavy gamer’s game, but I think it is suited for gamers too in between bigger games. Definitely take a look, it’s a splendid game (sorry, I had to do it)! It’s so simple yet strangely addicting – I know I am going to play it a lot more! It won’t be for anybody, but it was a hit for me.

RATING: 8
I've never seen a game draw people in so easily as Splendor does.  Easy-to-learn, fast-paced, with plenty of tension and well made components.  It reminds me a lot of St. Petersburg, with a lot of the administration (i.e. boring) parts removed.  I personally preferred this over Camel Up to win the 2014 Spiel Des Jahres.  

I thought I'd tire of playing it after a few times.  That hasn't happened.  

At least in four player games, there does appear to be a dominant strategy: reserve and/or buy up only the single color cards in the second and third rows (i.e. the cards that require 5, 6, or 7 of only one color).  With some clever hand management, this strategy seems to win a disproportionate number of games.

RATING: 8.75
Very simple-at-heart but has a good level of thinking. I love that fact that this is simple to set up, quick to play and very easy to learn/teach!

It plays fantastically with 2, 3, or 4 players, which is a real plus. Two players is more strategic whilst 4 is more tactical.

RATING: 9
Engine building/set collection game. Simple to introduce players to.

Scratches the same itch as dominion while being a much simpler game. Good amount of strategic decision making where you have to chose between a number of simple to comprehend choices. Depending upon the tiles and cards that come up there are a number of viable strategies - going for an engine that allows you to build up to inexpensive victory points or just rushing straight for the 5VP card. The 15VP goal is low enough that you can just rush points but high enough that sometimes an efficient engine is better.

Strategy varies depending upon the number of players playing because of the changing ratio of money/player, pursuing sets that nobody is going for and having more/less players to block.

The poker chips are a very satisfying weight.

RATING: N/A
Love this game, though I can see that it might not appeal to everyone since it's rather simple. In this game you collect gems (in the form of cards and poker chips) to purchase more gems, all with the goal of becoming a reputed gem merchant who may attract the attention of noble patrons. Certain gem cards have points, as do the noble cards you can obtain if you fulfill certain card hands, and the first person to 15 points wins. 

This is one of those gateway games that I can teach quickly to anyone and that will be fun to play as a 20-30 minute filler. I taught this to my husband's 70 year old grandma and she raved about how much she enjoyed it.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A game which boils down the pattern of snowballing to its utmost basics, stripping everything away that could possibly be interpreted as a distraction. It's even more basic in this approach than is ageing St. Petersburg; and probably attracts the same people too. Do not believe people who claim that the game is empty and without skill: they are wrong, and they know it. There is definitely skill in managing the turn order cycles, and whether or not to go for a blocking move instead of furthering your own position. These may be simple deliberations, but [i]simple[/i] is not the same as [i]absent[/i], which happened to be the point of the naysayers. 

However, I do also feel that once players begin to get a feeling for the various paths and options, that luck of the draw will [i]worsen[/i]. Someone who accidentally uncovers a 'free' card for his left neighbour for example puts himself in [i]gote[/i] through no fault of his own. It was just luck which caused the card to appear as it did. So between experienced players more lookahead is a must. This isn't difficult to accomplish, of course, but the absense of such a rule still dents Splendor's gleaming exterior.

In the end I think I like the game for what it is. It shouldn't be compared to much more difficult and complex snowballs, as it won't survive that comparison. This is not meant to be a gamer's game; I even think that a serious gamer will be done with it after a handful of attempts because it all boils down to discovering not-all-that-hot relations in the upgrade paths with ever lessening upgrade efficiencies. Nevertheless, given its strong limitations it actually accomplishes what it sets out to do rather well. This is an easy game to explain to families, and the artwork and solid gem execution aid this process tremendously. Consequently I'm generous with my rate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Now to be fair, not all play groups will have the same experience as mine, just saying, be warned if you have even semi-competitive people in your groups, this game can start to be a bit of a downer after awhile.

RATING: 7
This game is decent but deceptive to experienced gamers. It [i]looks[/i] like you should be able to build an engine by purchasing lower-level cards and eventually work your way into swiftly buying many expensive point cards/nobles for cheap. However, in reality, the game usually ends before the engine actually pays off.

Also, this game suffers from the same kind of randomness exhibited by Power Grid's auctions - you never know when buying a card from the table may just flip over a much better card for your opponents to buy. This is unavoidable and therefore mildly annoying.

An okay game if you don't take it too seriously.

Owned Expansions:

Cities of Splendor
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game lives up to its fast-earned reputation. First thing I noticed when I opened the box, after the great organization design? Amazing artwork! Every inch of this game is beautifully rendered, and the gem chips are so satisfying to hold and clack against one another, with the heft of thick poker chips. Completes the theme very well, highly pleasant to look at, and makes the overall game much more fun to play.

Splendor reminds me of the best part of the real time strategy games we all love: the engine-building phase - the central mechanic in this game of spending gems to purchase developments which, in effect, yield more gems, which build the engine to yield more developments, etc. The system is simple and elegant, flows naturally and seamlessly, and is very satisfying with immediately apparent benefits.

The game moves quickly, while there is a good amount of strategy, balancing between collecting gems, reserving and buying developments, and blazing a path to prestige points and acquiring favor from nobles, which takes careful planning with each step, with a view toward the final goals. Don't save up gems too long, or your fellow greedy merchants will steal your prize before you can get to it!

Great fun with lots of player interaction, a short, addictive game with good decisions that doesn't require a ton of brain power on a Friday eve - fantastic for families or any group who enjoys the thrill of a well-themed game of fortunes.

RATING: 8
You would think that a game with instructions this simple just wouldn't be any fun, especially when one turn is similar to the next.  But in fact, it's quite enjoyable and plays very fast.

Players can take a few different types of gems, eventually "buying" a card which will give a discount in the future.  You keep acquiring those and then have a number of turns where you can afford anything - but which ones to choose in order to get you the most points?  Or the favor of a visiting noble?  You also need to think about the endgame - once someone hits 15 points, the round plays out and it's over.  You have to be careful not to end things prematurely if someone can beat you on their last turn.

Super fast, super easy, thick tokens and nicely illustrated cards.  This is a great filler for gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Incredibly pure distillation of an infrastructure game. As usual, you want purchasing-power early and points late; the challenge comes from the constraints of what cards are available. (What you have to pay with may not be what the cheaper infrastructure cards require, or the colors they provide may not be what you need for nobles or for more expensive cards you're eyeing for later in the game.)

So you have to flow with the available options, which may sometimes mean breaking that "infrastructure first" heuristic, and *that's* interesting. (As is the potential for sniping out key steps in opponents' buildups, and the counter of reserving cards at a relative cost.)

RATING: 6
Splendor is an elegant, little engine builder with really nice components, but I can't honestly say that I enjoy it. The whole game is taking chips to buy cards to score points, while trying to mess up a bit with your opponent's plans in the process. Every single move is meaningful, but the overall experience is dry, solitaire and themeless. If you're looking for a light, yet interesting card drafting game, I'd rather play 7 Wonders Duel over Splendor any day.

RATING: 3
The description for a "3" reads "Likely won't play this again, although could be convinced.  Bad."  The pretty much sums up how I felt about this game.  I didn't have very much fun playing it.  Your mileage may vary.

It's nothing more than a mechanism.  You build an engine by buying stuff that allows you to buy more stuff more efficiently.  Eventually one player has fine-tuned their array to the point where they win.  There's nothing inherently wrong with that idea, but I'm frankly tired of "building an engine" when I should be playing a game.  I would rather be interacting rather than reacting.  This game felt like a lot of reacting: "Fred bought the card I thought I wanted.  Now what do I do?"  

Not my idea of fun, but I'd play it again with the right group.  It's 20 minutes of activity with the opportunity to cuss Fred out once in a while.

RATING: 3
I rate this game a 4 out of respect for the praise and enjoyment so many others seem to give and get from it. But honestly, I would be hard-pressed not to flatly refuse to play it again. I hated it that much.

It's just -- it doesn't feel like a "game" to me, it feels like a math problem. There's no luck or randomness really, it's just straight solving the best and most efficient way to score points based on the cards that are out there and how you can lightly interfere with another player by taking the last of a certain gem color. Where is the fun??? The theme is meaningless. The art is well-drawn but has no life to it.

This game is just so cold and soulless.

RATING: 7.5
[April 2015 - 7.5]
I was skeptical of Splendor despite all the high praise. It just didn't seem like my type of game. Then I played it at a game night and really enjoyed it. To me, this games kills 7 Wonders (minus its lackluster theme) because there's that same aspect of building up and taking other cards that people really want, but in a much more public and interactive way. I also really like the simple supply-and-demand economic system of the chips and the checks and balances it provides. Even the chip play is interactive in that you either need people to play their chips to free them up or grab chips before the other players do. In all, it fosters some of those great game moments when it isn't about your movement as much as it is guessing what the others will do.

RATING: 9
Comes to the table all the time.  With my kid, with gamers, with non-gamer friends.  After one quick game, everyone gets it.  Slick game.  Great poker chips as gems.

After several plays, I started seeing the different strategies - going for the nobles; going for gem cards that are important to acquire middle-tier cards; and all the while trying to stock up for a big 4 or 5 point 3rd tier card.  And on top of that, trying to combine these strategies to achieve more than one of them.  One of my most played games of the past several months.

RATING: 9
I originally rated Splendor a 7, but the more I play it the more I appreciate its elegant design. Baseball fans marvel at the 90-foot space between bases; the perfect distance for a quality defensive play but enough that any mistake is punished. Splendor's 15 point victory condition is the board game equivalent. This is a true classic and I would now honestly call it one of my favorite games of all time.

RATING: 5
Simple optimization game where players are building an income engine, obtaining gems, and investing income/gems into making that engine more efficient.  The cards increase the income, and the better cards award victory points.  Sets of cards attract Nobles, also worth points.  The game ends when somebody crosses 15 points, highest score wins.  

Nice looking, very simple game, in an oversized box with large, weighty poker chip gem pieces.  If you took the nice pieces away, I suspect this game would be seen for what it is - almost an activity in optimization that plays itself.  Harmless and pretty.

RATING: 9
You take gem tokens in order to trade up for better-value gems and attract the nobility. 

A very tight engine-building game. The heavy poker chip-like gem tokens are very satisfying to move around, and the artwork is bright and evocative, even if the theme is pretty light. 

The lightweight gameplay and quick playing time should make this an excellent gateway game. Best with 2 or 3 players. 

Not a perfect 10 simply since with four players it's harder to build a strategy and can be unsatisfying when your options are stripped away by the other players.

RATING: 6
The simplest possible engine-builder. Get gems, spend them for discounts on gems (some of which come with points). There's a reasonable amount of jockeying for in-demand gem colors, blocking in the form of reservation capability (which also gives wild gems that can ease pressure on particular colors). All of this is added to the conventional switching problem -at what point do I shift from infrastructure to points?

I appreciate simplicity, so this game is right in my wheelhouse, but I'm not sure the game is mean enough for me. Blocking can be more costly for you than for your opponents, as the gems they build up can be used to get alternate infrastructure/points. While this doesn't fit my tastes, it works well with newer or more conflict-averse players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
This feels like a game that is over-hyped.   The mechanics are dead simple...  take chips, or spend chips to play a card. RATING: N/A
An extremely good two-player game (can be played with 2-4 players). The game is pretty quick and addictive too. I probably played about 20 times during the first week I got it, mainly with two-players. 

It's an engine-building game in a way, where cards that you have played (they remain in front of you), will provide discounts for your future purchases. 

I played it with three once, and didn't like the downtime, although it's not long at all. Probably I'm so used to the speed in a two-player game.

After plenty of two-player games, I can see that the winning strategy lies on grabbing the noble cards. Getting 2/3 of the nobles bags you six points already, and that's a big deal. Getting all nobles then becomes a huge deal. One thing I didn't like much is how third tier cards are less claimed. Maybe not in a multi-player game.

Anyway, I was proved wrong one time, when my opponent (two-player game) won the game without any nobles, while I had three nobles.

RATING: 6.5
Such simple rules disguising a rather tense engine building game.  The tension is from the race itself, which always seems to be close no matter what you do, and the choices you have to make.  The forfeiting of a turn to reserve a card is a particularly interesting dynamic which presents tough decisions.

In some respects I feel that this is a fairly basic single mechanic which has been made into an entire game, and perhaps it would benefit in being as part of a greater game.  But then on the other hand this essential simplicity and short game-play is what makes the game so attractive.  So on balance I'm sold and have since purchased a copy. RATING: 10
One of the greatest drafting games. The theme is the worst part, it doesn't fit at all. It could be about recollecting fruits or lego parts, and in fact, it doesn't matter. 

It's a game for thinking for a while, trying to do the best move, and don't be far away for your opponents, by buying or reserving cards (that give you a bonus). You gonna have all your friends entertained and in some kind of silence, because of the game demands your attention for what type of gems are you picking up, and which one the others too. So, you could buy the cards without before the rest of the players. The main reasons to buy the cards before other players are 1) the price of future cards descend because the cards owned act like discounts; and 2) if you reach a goal of cards marked in other tiles (Nobles), you take them, giving you better chance to win the game. 

The game finished when a round is ended because a player reaches the 15 points (some cards and all nobles had values or winning points), that means that all players had the same number of turns.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In Splendor players are jewel merchants that are collecting different gemstones to attract the attention of nobles.  The theme is pretty much pasted on and it plays very much like an abstract game. 

During a turn, players choose certain gem chips or use collected chips to purchase cards that provide a certain type of gem and possibly score certain points.  The game play is very straightforward and easy to teach/learn.  The game plays like an engine builder and the strategy is different every game depending on what cards and nobles are in play.

Player interaction is limited to taking cards/chips that someone else might need.  Of all the games I own, this one plays the most silently as everyone is staring intently at the field and contemplating their moves.  Even Blokus has more trash talking!  

This is a fun game for those that dislike direct player conflict and want a short, strategic game that is simple and very elegant.  Definitely recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Splendor is a relatively quick race to 15 points. It's an engine-building card game where the players are collecting coloured chips to match various cards on a three-tier display of cards. The tiers increase in cost and points value. When taking chips, you either take three different colours or two of the same (assuming it has at least so many (it's more than two but I can't recall the exact number). When you complete a card, it goes into your tableau and gives you a virtual chip of a specific colour. You can also reserve a card which you want to build or your opponent wants to build and are given a consolation wild chip. Beyond the three-tiered display, there are some noble tiles which require sets of  specific-coloured cards to be complete to claim them. All of this drives a quaint, but relatively ho-hum system. It's quick and easy to play and explain, it's attractive, and probably a good gateway or family game. There are just other games that fit this category that I'd rather play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Although Splendor does not have layers of strategy that lead to post-game discussions about key moves that players made that cost/won them the game, it is an amazing game for the category it falls into: light, fun, quick to setup/teach/learn/play. Of course, I have to mention the quality of the components, too - specifically the poker-style gem tokens. Holding the tokens while you ponder your next move adds an unexpected pleasant aspect to the game. I find the game to be kind of addictive... when I finish one game I want to immediately play another!

RATING: 6
Splendor is a game of chip-collecting and card development. Players are merchants of the Renaissance trying to buy gem mines, means of transportation, shops—all in order to acquire the most prestige points. If you're wealthy enough, you might even receive a visit from a noble at some point, which of course will further increase your prestige.

On your turn, you may (1) collect chips (gems), or (2) buy and build a card, or (3) reserve one card. If you collect chips, you take either three different kinds of chips or two chips of the same kind. If you buy a card, you pay its price in chips and add it to your playing area. To reserve a card—in order to make sure you get it, or, why not, your opponents don't get it—you place it in front of you face down for later building; this costs you a round, but you also get gold in the form of a joker chip, which you can use as any gem.

All of the cards you buy increase your wealth as they give you a permanent gem bonus for later buys; some of the cards also give you prestige points. In order to win the game, you must reach 15 prestige points before your opponents do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Really interesting little set collection/tablaeu building game.
Gems come is 5 different colours and a wild colour and are used to but cards from the selection on board or one you 'reserved' earlier.

Cards have a free gem on them that you can spend each round and some have points upon them. First to 15 points wins.

Its not particularly strategic as it is dependent upon the gems available on your turn and what buildings are available but it is quite tactical as you can 'reserve' take to your hand cards which you know your opponent was about to be able to play.

I was initially concerned there would be a win more mechanic as the lower cost buildings are quick and easy to play and each card gives you a free gem a turn however this is not the case as the cost balance has been done very cleverly as whilst the free gems from previously claimed cards are needed to purchase the higher cost cards you also need a fistful of the correct colour gems.

Components are very nice and the poker chip gems are very good and have a good weight to them. There is a slight issue with the green/blue/black gems being very similar in colour and shape however the background pictures are different and so you can tell them apart.

Sold with Nobles promo in 2017.

RATING: 5
A minimalist engine building/set collection game. While it may seem like there is a decent amount of guessing your opponents' intentions and blocking going on at first, it soon turns out that a lot of it is just for show. Grabbing a tile just before someone else would isn't actually very effective if it is immediately replaced by something even better (usually: cheaper) and that happens a lot more often than you would think.

In the end, turning up the right cards at the right moment is a lot more important than any deliberate player move, a deficit that is amplified by an engine building scheme that rewards quantity instead of quality.

RATING: 6
Das größte Plus von SPLENDOR ist die Großzügigkeit im Spielmaterial: dicke, fette, pfundschwere Chips, die jedem Ocean Eleven-Casino in Las Vegas zu Ehre reichen würden. Die Dinger liegen in der Hand wie Münzen aus dem Schatz der 40 Räuber. Das Klappern beim Stapeln ist ein nervöses Wohlgeräusch vom Pokertisch. Auch die Personenplättchen hätten mit dünnerer Pappe den gleichen Zweck erfüllt, aber auch hier gilt Prosperität. So 1a das Materialbewusstsein, so konventionell das Spiel selbst: mit den Chips, die verschiedene Arten von Edelsteinen verkörpern, bezahlt man Karten, die Dauer-Edelsteine oder Punkte bringen und wer zuerst 15 Punkte hat, gewinnt den Bazar. Das haben andere auch schon 1001x gemacht im Orient. In seinem solitären Charakter dürfte SPENDOR zu zweit am Besten kommen, weil am Taktischsten, weil man hier Chips blocken kann. Unter Berücksichtigung der Zielgruppe Familienmitglied steht SPLENDOR als gute, solide Dutzendware im Regal von Karstadt, den die attraktive, aber ahnungslose Verkaufsberaterin auch ohne Wissen von Brett- und Gesellschaftsspielen vorbehaltlos empfehlen kann. Ihre Telefonnummer wäre mir lieber.

RATING: 3
While there is a tension between making plans and watching what other players are attempting to be able to preempt them by reserving cards, it comes down so fast to the luck of the draw being able to keep a color of gem away from a player or not (and as with many games of this preempting nature, there is a lot of left-right binding with which to contend).
Even ignoring the luck and downstream-malice, the biggest problem is a total lack of texture. Every color of development is of the exact same value with the exact same distribution and the exact same abilities. There is no unique strength or value to building particular developments or particular levels of developments, which makes players' tables basically the same and also makes the game feel the same every time it is played.

(6 plays)

RATING: 5.75
Easy to teach, elegant set-collecting game. Quite dry. The interaction is mostly coincidental, or part of the luck of the draw. However, it is possible to deny cards to other players. The strategy element comes from choosing which set to work on, as the sets provide discounts on future sets and/or points, and some cards are more efficient than others, and lend themselves to getting better cards in the future.  It plays relatively quickly. Arguably it's over-produced, but there's a certain charm in the hefty chips. 

Edit: upped the rating after more plays. Very nicely balanced.

RATING: 7.7
2 player variant:
In an attempt to keep our games closer to the feel of 3 & 4 player games, we’ve been using a 2 player variant(suggested in the games forum https://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/17132785#17132785 that removes half of the level one cards.
In 2 player games, there tends to be an abundance of level one gem cards. Players tableaus turn into a frantic back and forth of - I take a card - You take card - I take card - etc.  Having an excess of Level 1 cards in play diminishes the chips value much too quickly from the game.  The game often turns into a race for the nobles with victory going to the player that gets 2 of the 3 first.

Simply remove half of the level one gem cards by dividing them into two equal cost/valued sets. This assures an even split of colors and creates two “half level one gem decks” that can be used for consecutive games.

Taking out half of the level one cards with 2 players gives a similar feel to a 3 or 4 player game by bringing back the risk that the cards may/will run out part way the through the game. The reduction of the level one cards ensures that the chips are in demand throughout the game.  As a result, the level 2 and 3 cards are purchased more often as well as an added attention for the need to reserve cards. 

YMMV; but also suggest increasing to 20 victory points instead of 15 for 2 player games.

RATING: 8
This game is really good.  In under 5 minutes you can explain it and be playing it.  Sometimes, that's just important, and some people are only going to play a game where that is the case.

I've played 3 player, 2 player, and 4 player.  All games were tight, and moved quickly.

I haven't played enough to see a clear strategy as others seem to claim and refute.  It's certainly tactical vs strategic.  I can see this game popping out in a variety of groups and looking forward to getting it on the table a bunch coming up here. 

The components are great, and I think really help out a lot - you sort of just want to play with the poker chips.  In terms of value....I don't know.  I picked it up for 20 on a sale - I think for 30, it feels a little light.  But hey, if you like the game, it probably doesn't matter.

I keep it in the collection because its a fun diversion and especially good to play with non-hobby gamers. They love it! But for seasoned gamers, the game is probably just a bit too simple. What I don't like about the game is that it's fun for the first 15 or so moves when you have to collect chips to satisfy the card prerequisites. But if you play the game correctly, there is a tipping point where all you do is simply pull cards from the rows where you have already satisfied the demand through earlier moves. That's not fun. And at that point in the game it simply becomes a race to the finish and/or highly luck dependent as to what colors come off the stack and whether or not those are gems that you need for various mixes.

RATING: 6
Simple engine-building.  Easy to teach and learn, with nice presentation and components.

Take a resource chip or two, spend to buy a card.  Use said card plus more resource chips to buy more cards that give points and more resources...  repeat until target point threshold has been reached by one player.

This game did not excite me at all. Has minimal interaction, none of which is "direct", which lands it outside of my particular tastes. The amount of praise that it often receives just doesn't align with my opinions of it.  I don't find that it has any real "meat" and after half a dozen or so plays, I had no desire to play it again.  

Certainly not a bad game, as it's ease of understanding offers a nice introduction for some common mechanisms within the hobby. For this reason, it'll remain in my collection for a while longer.

RATING: 5
Very simple and abstract card game. You get gems to buy cards that provide permanent gems, and over time you increase your ability to buy more expensive and valuable cards. There is also some set collection that may give you bonus points in the form of nobles' tiles.

It works, but there really isn't much to the simplistic gameplay. My only game had a strange arc, very slow for the most part and then suddenly moving fast to the end, but it seems that it's very dependent on how the cards come out. There is obviously a significant amount of randomness, aggravated by the lack of any perceivable logic in the cost of different cards in the same deck. It may be a good fit for non-gamers and I wouldn't mind to play it once in a while, but it left me with the general impression that it isn't more than an oversized, overpriced, overlong (and seriously overhyped) filler.

The art is pretty and the sturdy tokens are nice, but in a game about precious stones, it's a real shame that the publisher missed the obvious opportunity to include some beautiful plastic gems.

I recently played Arboretum and I actually like it better for a short game, but it is really best at 2 when you go back and forth against one opponent. Therefore this is still my favorite 30 or less game since it plays equally well with any available count.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a relatively quick game.  It has lots of little decisions that make it slow to start, but then when it gets rolling, people start picking up cards for free or for 1 good, and the game can end in a big rush.

It reminds me of one of the things I dislike about Alhambra -- you plan to buy a card and save goods accordingly, but then the player to your left gets the card, and a new card shows up that you could also buy, but the next player picks that one up, and so on.  So there's a lot of luck-of-the-draw that seems unfair to me.  But I guess that's to be expected for a quick filler game like this.

It's very important to pay attention to what Nobles are available to be won, since it's a race to get them.  You could focus on getting cards with colours that could be used for more than one of those nobles.  For example, if there is a noble to be won for having 3 white, 3 blue, and 3 red, and another to be won for having 3 white, 3 blue, and 3 green, it would be good to pick up 3 white and 3 blue!

It might be a good idea to pick a couple of easy cards from the face-down pile at the beginning, so that you have a chance to go for something that nobody else knows about, and pick up a couple of gold coins (wildcards) as a side benefit.

RATING: 7.5
It's a perfect game. First of all: it's elegant and easy to get into: The theme is pleasing, but barely there, but it's not needed anyway: the abstract skill-rewarding gameplay stands on its own. The player interaction is indirect but, especially with more experienced players, stronger than it appears at first glance.

First I found it too streamlined and mechanic that it didn't excite me at all. After more plays, a deeper dive into the strategy, and my first wins, I realize that Splendor may be *the* benchmark for this kind of game: streamlined light/mid-weight filler that appeals to a *wide* audience and comes with great components.  My early verdict (in 2014) was: “Next year, next perfect game.” — now, mid-2016, I still don't see any game taking Splendor's place.

Rating history:
2014: 6.5
2015: 6.85
2016: 7.5

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game was the surprise of the game night. I didn't expect a lot from this one, however after playing it i changed my mind. The game is an abstract strategy game without a strong theme so what is insteresting about it? Well it is kinda an engine building game just like Fleet but in this one you can take the limited resourced before your opponents manage to take them. It has one of the easiest rules but the strategy is deeper than it first appears. After that i no longer wonder why this game is so popular. The playtime is around 40 minutes.

Pros / Cons:
-This game gives you an opportunity to kick ouf your opponents from the valuable resources to force them to buy from a more expensive one (golden).
-The rules are quite simple yet the strategy is deeper than that.

-Well it is hard to say bad about it, but im not sure if it has enough replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very good game, looks fantastic if a bit repetitive. Same art work is recycled on many cards. Doesn't take away the fact though that art itself looks good and fits the theme really well. Components are high quality and I appreciate that all the gems are weighty pieces of metal and plastic, giving more authentic feel of touching something with value, instead of doing that part just with cards (which would have been even easier but a lot more boring decision). Game is very simple, on your turn there's only a few things that you can do. Victory conditions are very clear too. In a very slight way this is like building an engine (even though this is not officially an engine-building game at all), because you have to build yourself a bonus-system that you can utilize in order to start collecting victory points as soon and efficiently as possible. This is once again one of those games that is easy to recommend as a gateway game for basically anyone who's even remotely interested about boardgames. It won't offer anything too extensive and for hobbyists it is something more casual and filler-like. Still, all said and done, as a family game or for more casual gaming, it's a perfect choice. Please do keep in mind that with Cities of Splendor you can considerably improve the experience. Must have for anyone who keep playing Splendor on regular basis.

規則:
1.人數+1的貴族版塊，每疊開四張，兩人寶石都只有四顆，三人都只有五顆，黃金都是全用
2.同色寶石要四顆以上才可以選擇拿兩顆動作，否則都是拿不同顏色三顆，寶石上限十顆
3.拿黃金可以選擇暗抽或明抽牌面的發展卡，保留手上上限三張，沒黃金拿還是可做保留卡選項
4.貴族版塊一次只能獲得一塊，如果條件符合兩塊也只能挑一塊

RATING: 5
Meh... it's technically a game.

In all seriousness, Splendor is a perfectly serviceable board game. That is to say, it has rules and game components that players use to achieve victory. Other than that, it's extremely bland. The theme is ridiculously unimaginative and not necessary to the game at all. You basically compete in a race to see who can make the best trades in the least amount of time. Splendor has all the functionality of a seedy, bad-part-of-town flea market with none of the excitement or danger.

RATING: 8
A great game, all-around. Splendor is an engine-building game. It's thin on theme, but rich in gameplay. It's easy to learn, but difficult to master. The game components are excellent-quality. The turns are short. Everyone at the table stays involved as the board and resources keep changing. The games are short enough that you're likely to play more than one game in a sitting. I foresee this being a regular at the gaming table.

Get this: If you like Dominion. If you like engine-building games (like Dominion). If you like your strategy games with a bit of luck. If you're looking to a "gateway game" other than Ticket to Ride.

Avoid this: If you hate strategy games. If you only like games with complex rules. If you play games for their themes (you could paste any number of themes onto this game and it wouldn't matter).

RATING: 6.7
Splendor is a set collection game where players collect gems and exchange them for resources that subsequently grant the player permanently available gems that count towards the exchange requirements of additional resources.  As a player accumulates permanent resources, he or she can better afford new, more valuable resources.  This mechanism results in a thrilling snowball effect.  

I've found that I pay very little attention to my opponents progress, so I wish that the game encouraged a bit more player interaction.  Otherwise, Splendor is an simple and enjoyable "filler" game.  The components are top notch. 

Rating: 6.7 (Fun 6; Gameplay 6; Components 10; Theme 5)

Formula:
[Weighted rating = (((Fun*4) + (Gameplay*3) + (Components *2) + (Theme *1))/10)]

A race type game with style. Very well made components.  Fun and light.  Stands up to repeated play.  I appreciate the effort that went into the design but the theme does feel "pasted" on.

Big discussion about pasted on themes but still like the mechanics in this game. Played three with Brian, won two.  I also got lucky.  We both noticed how the game speeds up somewhere in the fourth or fifth round. 

Played a very good game last night.  I made the mistake of not tracking my opponent's stockpile which would have been a tipoff of his strategy and averted a huge comeback victory for him. Do not treat this game like solitaire. It has more depth than that for sure. 

Played several online games.  A few bugs that I'm sure will be fixed.  But' gameplay was smooth and pace was excellent.  Not handling the chips has some getting used to but overall an excellent gaming experience.

RATING: 7
Splendor is a game that has grown on me. My initial impressions weren't great as I wondered what was so novel about its engine building that seemed to end before it could begin to really allow powerful moves. The more I played it, the more I found that it is about building the leanest engine possible, not the most powerful.

It has some issues - namely in the randomness department, especially with more than two players. The trade-off is that is makes a great gateway game as it is simple to explain and gives even first-timers an outside shot of winning.

After some consideration, it's earned a spot in my collection thanks to its simplicity and intricate challenge even for veteran players.

RATING: 4.5
2014-08-11

Initial Rating: 5.0 (August 2014)

I wasn’t expecting a very good game, so I wasn’t very disappointed, however I can say I found the game to be very light so I will sell it as soon as I can. I can see Splendor as a good game to bring new people into our hobby, but I don’t have any desire to play it again. It is not a bad game, it even has some (minor) interesting decisions, but as I find the game to be obvious, I think the luck of the draw can play a significant role. I could be mistaken as I only played it twice. The rules can be explained under two minutes.

The game IS gorgeous and the chips are heavy and feel great (I think this is its main appeal). The art is also of good quality. The game insert is useless as the game get disorganized very easy. 

Bottom line, an ok game for families or new gamers. It is very light for me so I won’t waste any more of my play time with it. I’m surprised it is ranked so high here on the geek, as of today it is 148. I suspect that if I play it again the rating will continue to go down.

RATING: 7
[b]Thoughts after first play[/b] [BGCOLOR=#66ff99] [b]8[/b] [/BGCOLOR]
Excellent, Excellent game. Replaces tons of card based fillers.

[b]Thoughts after tenth play[/b] [BGCOLOR=#66ff99] [b]8[/b] [/BGCOLOR]
Splendor is a gem of a game. Lu and I love it. On the surface, Splendor appears to be a simple card game. On your turn you can do one of four actions. Of those four, two will acquire you chips, and the other two gain you cards and the coveted wild chip.

Splendor plays quickly, but in a agonizing way. It’s fun, however the simplicity is a veneer that covers the hidden complexity and depth that only repeated plays start to chip away at. A game that by all accounts defines the term “filler game”, but in reality hides a complex economic game under it’s many layers.

Don’t let Splendor’s short rule book, and simple mechanisms lull you into a belief that this is a casual game. This game will have you quietly mulling over what to do from turn to turn, while carefully tracking your opponents card tableau trying to determine exactly how many turns you have left to amass the greatest fortune.

I recommend this game for any collection. Splendor is fun, small, easy to teach, hard to master, and has that certain quality of addictiveness that is oh so hard to capture in a game.

RATING: 7
A resource management game with a surprising richness for how simple the components are. The directions seem complicated at first blush, but there are very few mechanics to teach. It sets up and learns quickly.

I find that this game is a quiet experience. It can be tense, especially if you defensively take a card or a token when you catch on to someone else's strategy, but I generally find that Splendor plays are lower key. A good one for a game night with lower attendance numbers, and/or a mellower crowd.

I like to start typical game nights with the louder, more interactive games, but games like this are good for near the end of the night, when the potluck table is picked over and food comas are beginning to set in.

RATING: 5.5
A game with multiple paths to victory, but only one of those paths is the right one.  There are 2 problems with this game: 
1) There is little interaction because everyone is quiet while they are concentrating. 
2) There is a dominant winning strategy in this game that makes any other strategy seem like playing the sucker bets in craps. 

After many, many games of this.  The balance issues reared their ugly head.  The winning strategy is to go for the high value point cards every time.  You can reserve the points you need to win, and no one can stop you, they can only hope to reach 15 points faster than you.  This works almost every time; the exception is when all but one player is playing this strategy and the remaining player is free to collect the nobles without interference and no need to block anyone.  Otherwise, it is very hard to win by going for nobles because it is almost impossible to both block someone and go for your noble cards at the same time.  A better balanced game would make both strategies - high value cards and nobles - viable every time during every game.

RATING: 7
The gams is fascinating, because it is so simple. There are just a few rules, however plenty of decisions to make. You have to choose, which cards to save for and which cards to take into you hand so that others won't steel them from you. Do you need three different chips or two of the same sort? By the way, the opportunity to take two of the same occurs not that often. Finally, it is important to pay attention to what nobles are available. To sum up, it is not that easy to find the best way to victory.

RATING: 8
Belle découverte, un jeu avec règles simples et décisions intéressantes comme je les aime. L'interaction vient du fait qu'il faut surveiller les possibilités des autres pour leur subtiliser les cartes avant qu'ils ne le fasse. Un peu trop de cartes accumulées à mon goût (on a complètement vidé la pile 1, je ne sais pas si c'est fréquent). À la fin, nous avions tellement de cartes que le jeu se jouait presque tout seul (on pouvait aisément prendre des cartes gratuites ou presque). Thème absent, froid pour ceux qui ont besoin de se sentir un marchand, un entrepreneur, un architecte ou quoique ce soit - on fait seulement acheter des cartes sans signification. Pour ma part la simplicité, la mécanique, la qualités des décisions et la durée relativement courte font en sorte qu'il est définitivement à rejouer, avec un achat possible si concluant. 8/10. (04-2014)

RATING: 6
Management of five different currencies on two levels. There's a variable form of currency with limited total quantity for you to have and you use this form to generate the permanent form of currency that isn't spent when you use it. The latter form also contains the main bunch of your points. You have to have an engine in the permanent form of currency to do well, but at the same time you shouldn't forget making points by acquiring more expensive and harder to get pieces of the permanent currency. There's also some neat outguessing and very nice components included. After several plays I've formed a stern opinion that if you focus on blue, white and big buildings and forget red, green, engine building and nobles you're likely going to do well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Dry, bland, themeless, multiplayer solitaire at its worst.  Game has some good engine building elements, but ends just as soon as you ramp up to tier 3.  Does require skill and strategy to play, however too many choices are sub-optimal, sometimes unintuitively so.  For example, going for nobles is actually a poor play despite ostensibly being the POINT of the game.  You're better off reserving a top-tier card or two (if they have many common color requirements), then ramp up an engine solely to buy that(those) card(s).  If also you do this by focusing on tier 2 cards to build your engine as much as possible, you will leave players going for nobles in the dust.

RATING: 6
This double-drafting game seemed fairly clever and entertaining. Players draft from limited resource pools, then use these to draft cards which may or may not be worth victory points but which always give card discounts and contribute to bonus objectives. A good overall strategy is to not have the same overall strategy as the player on your right, since this heavily influences your rate of freebies. Now, both of our games had runaway victories decided several rounds before we actually stopped playing: whoever comes out of the first age with a few more freebies and claims the first noble is most likely to get a second and seal the deal. Also the age three cards might as well not have existed. If this pattern holds it would put a dent in the game's elegance. Well-deserved poster child for ridiculously oversized boxes.
