RATING: 2
Having played it a few times I’d say that:
1.	The theme is abandoned as soon as you open the box, since it has no relationship with the mechanics.
2.	The aim is to snowball by buying stuff of identical worth until you can buy stuff that’s worth a bit more.
3.	The game consists of a pair of double steps: wait for your turn, pick up chips, wait for your turn, buy a card …
4.	… until you have so many cards that you don’t need to pick up chips any more and your turn now consists of wait for your turn, buy a card.
5.	Each player obsessively wants the same thing: the right card to build a set. If you share that ambition this gives the game the same addictive feel as solitaire. If you don't, you might get the same enjoyment from punching and sorting out the counters from a new box of Eclipse.   
6.	The main tactical decision you can make is to block another player. 
7.	You can make no other significant decisions.
8.	You can take no risks.
9.	There is no tension, only mild frustration (I wanted that card. Oh, well.). 
10.	The analysis, if you can be bothered, amounts to a dreary mathematical problem.
11.	The snowball effect and the luck of the draw determine who wins.
12. The end feels like oh, you (or I) won. Gosh. 
13.	The replayability is close to zero unless you like games of obsession governed by chance.
14.	It’s not so much a socially entertaining game as a tedious, obsessive slog. 
15. This is solitare in which you can be frustrated by other players.
16.	It has the merit of being over quickly.
17.	Perhaps not quickly enough.

RATING: 8
A design that epitomizes elegance.  A modicum of rules easily explained in a few minutes, yielding quite a bit of depth for a game that can be played in half an hour.  Set up and break down is also a breeze.  I think this is one of the best gateway games to come out since Ticket to Ride, but one I usually enjoy playing more.  I've had a lot of success introducing it to non-gamers.  Not for everyone, as it is a bit dry and the theme is clearly pasted on.  I call it a "chin stroker" since I find the game lends itself more to silent pondering than to table talk.  Also, can start to feel a bit samey after many plays, but I'm closing in on 50 plays and have yet to tire of it.

approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  50+

RATING: 9
This has quickly become one of my favourite games and friends are always requesting it on game nights. It plays very smoothly for 2, 3 and 4 players and has a surprisingly amount of depth for a game that is very easy to teach new players. I love it for it's easy learning curve because I can use it as a gateway game but it still retains depth and challenge even after dozens of games. My group routinely plays 3 or 4 games of Splendor in a row before moving to another game. It's very well balanced and it's rare that any one player has a runaway victory.

If there is one criticism, the box is way to big for the size of the components, but I just put all the components in an Ultra Pro deck box and it travels amazingly well, I take this to the park all the time in the summer.

RATING: 8
Splendor is amazing in that it's rulebook is one page, it's easy to learn, there's very little barrier to sitting down and playing. The Game moves fast, you can play a game in 45 minutes. The art is top notch, it's given so much thought thematically from mine to marketplace idea conveyed. And it's far more complex to master than it's simplicity implies.

It's not higher because if you're looking for a game with depth, that has gameplay, story and environments that grow throughout the course of the game, Splendor isn't going to provide that.

RATING: 6

Minuses: Playing Splendor consists mostly of intensely & silently staring at the cards and gems, so it isn't a whole lot of fun. It's also best at fewer players (I prefer it with 2), as the more there are players, the less interaction there is as you can't really affect other players' plans.

RATING: 10
Play splendor once and you're hooked. The container box is ridiculously large, the poker pieces are too heavy to take it with you on holiday, and the rules could be explained more clearly.

But what an amazing game (you'd never expect that from Ravensburger, the logo equivalent to 70's housewives doing 1000 piece puzzles of a yacht scene).

In essence, splendor has a certain Soul, or call it personality, in it, that seems to come alive when you play. After 1 game everyone wants another, and another and so on. There is nothing like it. Great building system, great interaction, stuff to go for that makes a difference...

Play this game with gamers and it becomes very deep. Awesome, a keeper. 

A slight minor is the box size, mostly air, but easily fixed by cutting up the board.

RATING: N/A
Splendor is a fast-paced and addictive game of chip-collecting and card development. Players are merchants of the Renaissance trying to buy gem mines, means of transportation, shops—all in order to acquire the most prestige points. If you're wealthy enough, you might even receive a visit from a noble at some point, which of course will further increase your prestige.

RATING: 7
There's nothing that exciting or interesting with this filler game.  Best thing about Spendor is it's done in 15-20 minutes.

An abstract of converting gems (currency) to gem mines (cards that provide automatic currency), all for the purpose of gaining most victory points (mines with VP plus nobles worth VPs).  Not bad but nothing grand or exciting that sparks me to suggest playing it.  

Fundamentally, it's a race of who gets to 15+ VPs first and many times, it's won by whomever gets the most nobles with solid foundation of gem mines.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I think Splendor has forever earned a spot in my Top 10 List. It would take quite a few amazing games to bump it down far enough to put it at risk of ever being removed. The accessibility of this game is unrivaled. There is not a better gateway game that has ever been produced, because it appeals to all ages so well. Because of that, no single game may have done more for the gaming industry than Splendor. I think it has brought more people and families back into boardgaming than any other game in the past few years. The rules are simple, and very easy to learn in under 3 minutes of explanation. But the underlying strategy beneath the surface of these simple rules and mechanics is unbelievable. And I don't think many reviewers see that complexity hiding so inconspicuously beneath the welcome exterior of the beautiful and simple components.

RATING: 1.5
I really can not understand the hype around this game and the high ratings. I think so many people could have come up with this game but thinking it was so dull and cheap they threw that idea away. 

It's like a deckbuilding game engine but without deckbuilding ... It's like dominion (already non-thematic), take away the best aspect of dominion (deck building), add more type of coins and you get this residu. This is the pinnacle of non-creativity of boardgaming and it saddens me deeply so many people actually like it, it's a real demotivation for aspirant game designers like me. I don't want to make garbage, but apparantly garbage sells. 

The boredom is supported by the runaway nature of the 'design'. How a runaway leader game sells anno 2014 is beyond me. I guess poker chips is the way to design games today.

I rather play a 24h Monopoly marathon than one more game of this torture.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A solid little set collection/engine building game. Nothing super special here and the theme is pasted on despite the good artwork, but very clean execution. Works pretty well as a family/gateway game. 

Besides chaining your cards to spend the fewest gems as possible, there is strategy in prioritizing colors that are required for a lot of  goals, hoarding gems until a card everyone shows up, and tactics of reserving cards you want and taking gems that are low in quantity. 

The cons of this game is the engine building snowballs easily, which can create runaway leader if someone just plays super poorly, and there isn't a good way to mill for cards you want, so sometimes you will have e.g. 4 cards completed with diamond bonuses but nothing to use it on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
A solid economic Euro that plays relatively fast.  It plays almost quickly enough to be filler.  You can gather gems on your turn or buy cards which provide virtual gems, to be used later. You can also take a card and gold for reserve.  There are three banks of cards with different values.  Higher values are harder to get out.  First player to 15 wins.  

The game is solid, but I think it gets played a lot due to its simplicity and speed not because it is a ground-breaking game.  Art and components are very good.  It is a family weight game.

RATING: 8.1
It is a great game, well polished, great components (e.g., the heavy chips) with a good length (short enough) and good replayability.  Easy to teach, I can see this as a good introductory and gateway game.  I am not a fan of purely abstract games and therefore will not prefer it over other choices, but for what it is, it is excellent.  Also, it is somewhat MPS but has enough interaction, especially for a Euro.  Players tend to focus on their own tableaus but the tableaus are simple enough that after a while you pay attention to the drafting and denials and interact with other players.  One of the games that is good to have in one's collection, it fills a good niche and sometimes it is just the game you want to bring out.  Sustains repeated back to back plays.

RATING: 8
A very enjoyable game, whether with 2, 3 or 4 players.  It's a great game for non gamers as it's easy to learn.  This game could also be a gateway game to other trading games.

There are deeper, more complex trading games out there, this one never fails to disappoint.  Though the rules are simple, the level of strategy can be quite deep and there are multiple tactics that can give you a victory.

Appropriate and teachable to young, old and non-gamers.  I see Splendor as a must have in any gamers collection.

RATING: 6
Interesting simple (not very strategic) card game with money. 
This is all about creating a stone engine with cards, that let you buy more expensive cards, that will bring you the 15 points you need to win this game.

This game has some great play coins that on their own are worth the money. I had the feeling though, that you cannot do much wrong in this game. Whatever you do, it always brings you something and you are dependent on the cards that show up in the display when it's your turn. Still it's a fun game to play when your head is tired.

Minus: 2 - 5 - 6 - 10

RATING: 7
It takes a while to move on and get past the quality of the chips in this game. When you do the game is just as good.

A real thinky, planning and efficiency reward game set in the world of jewels. Where nobels are inexplicably drawn to you when you have enough gems (and I thought it was my personality that drew all the nobels to our door)! Needless to say I am not that great at it. My family do enjoy playing it, but not the youngest daughter and my son. They don't like it when you reserve a card they were planning to buy on there next go. A Mexican stand off with my youngest daughter resulted after I attempted (an attempt was as far as I got) to reserve a card she was planning to buy.

"I'm so angry I could just ... just ... rip this card in half!" she said as she held out the card between us, gripping it with a Chinese burn ready to tear it in two.

"Don't!" I yelled in blind panic having never faced anything like this before in gaming (I didn't ever think of Splendor as a legacy game). I held out my arms with palms pacifyingly upwards unsure what to do or how to react to this small bundle of terrifying wildness. "I ... I ... I don't actually have to reserve that card. I have just had a better idea."

"You have! Well that's good then" She said sitting back down.

She eventually relented and I now have a sturdily premium sleeved game of Splendor.

Great for the family but not so great with younger kids! Keeper.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is such a great game.

It's juuuust barely not an abstract, in a way that reminds me a lot of classic Knizia (Battle Line, Lost Cities, and the like), and everything under the hood is amazingly tight -- also just like a Knizia design.

Every game opens up a new layer of things to notice, learn from, react to, figure out, assess, plan around, build, play with, or try out. It walks and talks like an engine builder, but it doesn't have to be played that way.

I love the mix of strategy and tactics, which is right in my sweet spot for a shorter game like this one. (Short, but meaty!) You can go in with a plan, but it might change once you see what comes out in the initial spread. And everything that happens after that will require further adjustments, from "Oooh, that card is great!" to "Shit, he's going to get that noble first unless I..."

And all of that is wrapped up in one of the best inserts I've ever seen! With, to top it all off, amazing components. The cards are beautiful, but also clear from every angle and across the table. The choice of poker chips (nice heavy ones, too) was inspired.

I love this game. Instant classic.

RATING: 7

Rating based on 2-4 players, but mostly 2.

Simple to teach and play, but there's a fair amount of depth to it for its length (which is nice and snappy). A good blend between making plans based on the high value cards and nobles available, but having to change those plans quickly depending on what cards are drawn.

Scales well between 2-4 players, but how you play the game will change dramatically depending on player count. I tend to use this as an introductory game.

Box Insert: 8/10, but close to breaking into the 9s. The main problem is that the wells spill too easily if the box gets turned upside down. As you are putting the game away everything should make you happy as it fits nicely and even had the games logo in the plastic, but an insert is more than just about putting things away, its about taking it back out next time you play. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
While I enjoyed my first game, it soon became clear in our second game that the runaway leader / snowball effect meant that luck was a dominating factor.

Perhaps it was just very unlucky, but our second game resulted in one person getting 6 or 7 cards in a row early on (i.e. without having to pick up any tokens), most for free and the rest for one token. Prior to that lucky streak the game had been quite close (everybody had 1 point, and 5 +/- 1 development cards), but in the end that person reached 15 points while the other three of us each had 3 points (IIRC they had ~13 development cards while we each had ~7)!! Furthermore, the other three of us did try to gang up on that person for the last couple rounds (e.g. using gold coins in a vain attempt to block a winning move, discussing all possibilities openly), but it didn't matter... every card we took revealed another one they could grab outright, or could just reserve with a gold coin and claim for victory in the next round. Just to elaborate how bad this was: the leader could grab multiple cards in the third row, while none of us other three could buy even a single card in the second row (first row was empty at this time).

It's hard to explain just how bad this game was... two of the people involved will never play again (including the purchaser of the game!). I'm personally willing to play once more just to see if I'm missing anything (how in the world is this ranked 97?!?). I also re-read the rules to ensure we didn't miss anything (the rulebook is very clearly written, and the rules are simple to learn and understand). The only rules I hadn't known were a limit on 3 reserved (but not yet purchased) cards, and picking one noble if two are triggered at the same time; but neither of these had any relevance to the 'game' we'd just played.

Edit: Played some more. Still convinced this game is garbage. Pass.

Great as a gateway game, particularly for spouses.

For I can't fathom why if we are merchants why we just collect gems. We never sell them. The theme could have easily been something like collecting butterflies, which would have made more sense. And what are the "black" gems? I know of no black gems. That could have been easily rectified by using another (brighter) color of gem (like purple Amethyst, light blue Aquamarine, pink Rose Quartz, or yellowish/orange Topaz). Anyway, the game works, but seems very pedestrian, like they churned it out in an afternoon. The artwork on the cards is nice, but has no bearing at all on the game and almost none on the theme (example, a picture on one of a tunnel under a bridge - wtf ?). In a word I found it boring. I could be coerced into playing it again, but I'd NEVER ask for it.  For if I want a set collection filler that has a better theme I'll play my Sobek.  
06/30/15 Coerced into playing half a four-player game in 46 minutes. Thank goodness we didn't have time to finish it!

RATING: 6
a short, light, entertaining set collection game.  On your turn you may either take gems (the game's currency), spend those gems to buy cards from the display, or reserve a card for yourself to buy later (getting a gold ["wild" gem] also).  The cards purchased have a gem pictured, permanently giving the holder that gem to spend every turn.  Also, some of the cards give points, ranging from 1 to 4.  The game ends on the round when someone gets at least 15 points.

RATING: 8
This might be my new go-to gateway game.  It appears to be a straight forward engine building game...well it is... but there is more complexity and more strategic options than at first appears.  After 5 games, I'm still looking forward to trying different things.

The real allure here is a very simple rule set with some depth and a short play time that escalates quickly.  Indirect player interaction is enough to keep from being multi-player solitaire, while not turning off confrontation-disliking players.

Components are really amazing.  They're almost over the top, but the components take it from being a good game to a great one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I played this game with Liz and some other guy whose name I forget. It was pretty much a Euro, by which I mean exactly like a Euro, by which I mean you're just taking turns doing a solitaire kinda sorta math problem thingie about nothing in particular and then counting up points.

What is the deal with "engine building?" If this game were a car, it would be [i]just[/i] an engine, sitting by the curb, humming along efficiently under the admiring stares of the unsmiling. An AmeriTrasher would walk up and ask, "What does it do?" And the admirers would just shrug and say, "But look how it hums!"

I'd like to say that at this point--finally--something explodes. But it's not that kind of game.

But hey, two points for Liz.

RATING: 7
Easy-to-teach, game. The fast pace and reduced playing time make it enjoyable.  Initially, after a dozen of games, we thought we figured out the optical tactics and felt it a bit repetitive. Then (after spending also a lot of time playing with the app) we realised it is  not so easy to find the optimal trade-off between resources and points, due to the need of reaching as fast as possible the required amount of Prestige Points. In four players the game seems more complex in term of choices but also a bit more random (difficult to predict what cards will be available in your turn).

UPDATED ON 19/2/18: since December 2017 my wife and I have been playing often the app version (especially when we are distant), reserving the board game mostly for more than two players.

RATING: 9
After 9 plays, my wife and I (mid 30s part-time Eurogamers w/young kids) love this game!!

It is quick to understand, easy to play, and leaves you with that "Let's just play one more time" feeling.

We love engine building games, but our lifestyle allows us to play mostly just quick games.  Splendor satisfies both of these criteria.   Sometimes we each wish that the we had a couple more turns in the game to better realize the output of our engines (and it would be easy to allow this, simply raising the number of victory points required to trigger the last round).  However, doing this would clash with criteria #2.

As a side note, our 2-year old twins love to play with the gem chips!!  They just sort them by color/gem into the pockets in the box insert and then declare "all done."  They actually request this game more than some of the kids games we have purchased to play with them.

RATING: 6.5
:r:eviewed:
[thread=1305182][/thread]

First - amazing production values that make it a joy to own and behold I love the art - really great stuff. 

Early thoughts:

Game can suffer from significant AP. Unsurprising given the range of options available.

Really think there should be a score chart. Keeping an eye on all opponents' scores is a bit of a pain.

Dislike that consecutive turns can pass when your best decision is simply to buy a card at zero cost. It's a forced optimal move that removes meaningful decision making.

Early rating: 5

Upped to 6.5 and heading upwards.

RATING: 10
Love this game. The artwork is gorgeous, the jewels are heavy and tactile. The game plays easily, and there is lots of planning and contingency planning.

I've played this game several times now, and every time I play, each player is incredibly invested in the game. It's impressive when brand new players can become immediately invested in the strategy.

Admittedly, the theme is pretty much absent in the game. You never feel like you're a jewel merchant hiring workers or operating mines. However, I would argue that the mechanics come first in this game, and boy are they spectacular.

Splendor was voted BGG's 2014 Game of the Year (beating out Dead of Winter), and I absolutely agree.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Splendor does what not many games do in that it wraps up a brain-burner experience into a simple, quick almost filler game package. It's quick, so it's not a big commitment, but it's not a dumb little game not much thinking. What results is a game where everyone feels satisfied because each turn is a meaningful decision (with just enough choices to be a thinker but not so many that you get analysis paralysis), and everyone wants to play again because it was so quick. The combination of it being both quick and so strategic makes it addicting. Also, every single person I've introduced the game to raves about the components - everyone loves poker chips! 

If there's one thing that is keeping this game from being perfect in what it is, it's that the theme is lacking. The theme itself is unclear - we're gem merchants? Trading, no selling, no buying, ... I'm not sure what we're doing, but we're doing SOMETHING with gems! And the game mechanics, while elegant and fun, don't contribute to the theme.

The only thing I wish this game came with was some sort of playmat. I purchased a third party custom playmat for the game and it really elevated the experience. 

Really looking forward to the expansions.

RATING: 7
An elegant, quick, and simple game that is easy to teach and learn. But, there is also a lot of strategy and depth to the game despite how easy it is. It's a game that is easy to introduce to non-gamers, and everyone will have a good time.

I like how well everything in the game works. Going for a few big point cards, or going for lots of smaller cards to build a stronger engine. Playing for the nobles. Denying cards and/or gems from other players. It all just works so well. 

The game scales excellently from 2-4 players. It's a great game to have - it can be a little bland which means it doesn't get to the table as often as it should, but when it does I'm never disappointed.

RATING: 3
If you need a special thing-in-a-box  just to teach non-gamers the basics of resource management mechanism to use in actual games, buy this one.
For all other occasions, this is overly simple and dull. I get it, gateway games are supposed to be simple, but this is way too trivial even for a gateway game.
No chance to manipulate card order, just a pure abstract chase for victory points... whoever gets his turn in the moment when good cards randomly come to play is likely to win. And I quite like abstract games, I just don't understand why do they need to add a totally non-connected theme. And I am perplexed by the hype.

RATING: 9
This is a fantastic engine building game. Like 7 Wonders, it plays very quickly but it still feels like you get a deep strategy experience. Even with such simple rules, there are many different paths to victory. You can try to build your engine with many cheap Tier 1 cards, or rush to the second and third tier to collect points and hopefully end the game early. But it's also a good idea to try and satisfy the nobles.

I very much recommend it. The only problem is that there is a lot of information on the table which means that sometimes you don't notice some of the possible options, and players may be overwhelmed when looking at all the cards in the offer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this game, there are five different colors of gems, plus a 6th color, gold, which acts as a joker. Players use gems to buy development cards (which provide more gems or give VPs) and they may be able to attract nobles for more VPs. The mechanics are very simple (collect gems, reserve card and gain a gold or buy a card). 

There is a lot of angst waiting to see if the card you want is going to get snapped up by an opponent, and you have to decide if you want to reserve a card. There is a race element to be the first one to 15 VPs, and also a race to see who can get the nobles first. It's a lot of fun, and I'd like to get in more plays. 

I can see the strategy progression in this game. First we tried to buy row 1 cards for cheap and get the nobles, now we have progressed to reserving row 2 cards (6 gems for 3 VP as it is the most economical). I can hardly wait to see how the next games go and looking forward to more plays. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.2
I really liked the look, feel, gameplay, and elegance of this game. It has a huge amount of replay value and a quick set up and take down for the layers of strategy it offers in what is essentially an elegant and simple card drafting and resource management game. I actually prefer this game over 7 wonders--not that they're incredibly similar but I do like it. That being said, it is fundamentally an abstract game and mistakes you make early can really hold you back throughout but I can see this being incredibly fun between several players who are all seasoned and played multiple times. Luckily, because it's simple and easy to teach and fast, it's quick to get people to become seasoned. Definitely a winner despite being largely abstract which is usually quite a negative for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like this game quite a bit, but I do have some issues though:

1) If you compress it, it takes up about 1/4th of the box...I really wish they hadn't made it so extravagant/obnoxiously big. I know it goes with the Splendor theme of rich extravagance, but I wouldn't have minded slightly smaller gems in a much smaller box.

2) At least at 4P, it switches to a more tactical game than strategic one, and its harder to plan long term - there's not much you can do if your plan happens to overlap with the two players next to you and the fourth takes advantage. Once you're behind, you stay behind but fortunately the game ends pretty shortly and skill will prevail more often than not.

There are some ways I think this game could've been improved (personally at least): more variant rules and objective/bonus cards to spice up the game some more (ex: set number of turns variant, most greens gets a bonus, fewest cards gets a bonus, etc - these are just ideas, I'm sure the designer could come up with better if he had time), player mats to track the chips and cards (not necessary but its a nice touch as players may miscount the number of chips they have and the box has a lot of space), and I wouldn't have minded more nobles.

As far as similarities, I think this game feels extremely similar to both Ticket to Ride and Dominion, but I prefer Splendor. Light ish theme, engine building, card generation...I do like that its easier to set up though and no shuffling, so I do prefer it, though there's no special or cool effects (which is part of the allure, its simplicity). Its selections are similar to TTR's and its close simplicity wise too, though its time is much faster and more consistent than both. Interaction wise, its mostly blocking, which I don't mind.

One small issue is how gunning for VPs can get you the 15 VPs really quick, which changes this from the engine game I thought it was originally. Not sure how I feel about this, but I could always play to more points if I want a longer game.

Plays: 20+

RATING: 8
Quick game of picking up different colored chips to pay for cards.  If there are enough chips, you can take two of one color, otherwise you are taking three of different colors.  

As you collect and pay for cards, you will be able to buy level 2 and 3 cards because each card will also count as a permanent chip at your disposal.  There are also characters you can bring to your cause if you collect, for example, three blue cards, three white cards, and three black cards.

First to 15 points wins.  

I like this game, and you would be surprised by someone beating you in a way you hadn't thought could win!

RATING: 3
Splendor is everything I both love and despise about modern board games. It is a simple design that is easy to teach, keeps runaway leaders to a minimum, plays equally well with 2-4 players, plays quickly and quietly in about 30-45min depending on AP... and it is SO dry.  You can hear the math in your head as you plot out your turns, and it gets very repetitive very quickly.  Also, the theme is nonsense; you are solving a math puzzle, and the game never lets you forget that.  The buy-in rate for non-gamers on this game, which is its target audience, is nearly zero.

The shine wore off Splendor in record time.  It occupies a space along with Kingdom Builder and will probably win awards like crazy, but yeah, I'm done.

UPDATED: Stop asking me to play this game.  Especially if you're going to analyze every single move to the point where it becomes a 45min game.  Here's how you win: Go for the Royals.  Don't do anything that isn't going to help you eventually win 1+ Royals.  It's literally that simple.

RATING: 8
[b]Splendor[/b]* was reaquired 11/2/17 and then sold via auction 2/19/17. 

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]Update - this was one of the games my kids told me they missed when we went through our previously owned list. I decided to pick it up again for them and because the short play time will fit in better with our current gaming availability. 

The first time I played it I was completely underwhelmed. Then I got the game as a gift and played it a lot with my kids over the course of a month. Then it fell off a cliff, I think we all got tired of the game play and complete lack of a theme. A lot of people have mentioned that this is a great gateway game, but I strongly disagree. I don't think it holds up to repeated play which to me is a huge part of what defines a good gateway game (Ticket to Ride and Camel Up come to mind).

I will also mention that I absolutely agree with Camel Up winning the Spiel last year. Camel Up has delivered every time I pull it out whether it is family, gamers and more casual gamers. I don't think Splendor holds a candle to Camel Up.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]- Easy to teach, quick play time.
- Great family game.
- Beautiful components [i](yes this is definitely part of the appeal of this game).[/i]
- Stripped down version of 7 Wonders [i](collecting resources to buy other card types).[/i]
- 3 levels of cards which are worth more points and provide you with a resource.
- Bonus nobles can really change how you play the game.
- You need to pay attention to your opponents and possibly take cards you don't need so they don't score easy points.[/i]

[i]*Was traded away with Dixit Origins and Le Havre: The Inland Port for Blue Moon City 10/31/14. [/i]

RATING: 7
心得:
輕快的策略遊戲
規則簡單，遊戲過程很快
要思考的還是不少
不過應該很快就能掌握訣竅
規則:
1.人數+1的貴族版塊，每疊開四張，兩人寶石都只有四顆，三人都只有五顆，黃金都是全用
2.同色寶石要四顆以上才可以選擇拿兩顆動作，否則都是拿不同顏色三顆，寶石上限十顆
3.拿黃金可以選擇暗抽或明抽牌面的發展卡，保留手上上限三張，沒黃金拿還是可做保留卡選項
4.貴族版塊一次只能獲得一塊，如果條件符合兩塊也只能挑一塊

RATING: 6
One of those games where you can play it as a light filler and let it play itself, taking the obvious chips for cards you can buy before the other players will have the requisite chips, and therefore buying cards as they present themselves. Or you can study exactly what chips all the other players have at all times, what cards they're intending to go for next and alter your plans accordingly. Put me in the former bucket. With new cards coming out all the time, taking the extra time is probably worthwhile results-wise, but just not worth it given the luck and the slowing down of the game for the other players. Take chips, buy cheap cards that allow you to build with less chips later, build an engine accordingly, buy bigger cards worth VPs, hope cards come out that you can buy cheaply and that the same doesn't happen to the other players - then you'll enjoy the win. Take chips or take a card. Every turn. Not that interesting. Ok for what it is, but too decision-light and theme-light and fun-light to warrant a lot of replay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As a gateway game, everyone I have introduced it to has liked it.  As Eurogamers, my wife and I can play this game in 20 minutes with our eyes closed.  It doesn't offer a lot of meat.  We have to hold our tongues when watching new players agonize over what they should do on their turns.  It's a pure engine builder, so what a person should do on their turn may be easily apparent to experienced onlookers. Nevertheless, we cannot deny that it has been successful when used as a gateway game. 

But so has ticket to ride.  And ticket to ride is better because although it is a gateway game, it still has something for gamers.  It has tension in the forms of: 'push your luck', 'take that', and secret objectives.  So as a gamer, I enjoy introducing people to ticket to ride more than Splendor.  Overall, I'd put it in my "good game" category - a rating of 7.  Not OMG great.  But still good.

RATING: 7
"Good, but overrated, abstract engine-building game. It's OK, but my brain has trouble calculating card gems + chip gems (+ wild gems), and relies a bit too much on denial for my tastes. Rating went from 6 to 7 with more plays. I won't ask to play it, but won't resist either. "

What I like:
- Easy to teach and learn
- The chips have a nice heft
- Plays quickly (45 minute 3p learning game)
- I like engine-building

What I don't like:
- Abstract
- Relies heavily on denial (including hoarding)
- Excessively large box

This is a decent little game. Thinkier than it appears, although it can be played (poorly) without much strategy. I think it's awfully dry (and thinky) for an SdJ, but abstracts have won before. I have trouble seeing why so many people are going gaga over it, but I suppose it does have a bit of Knizia-like minimalist charm.

Although there are no attacks (yay), I really dislike the form of interaction. If I reserve a card, I might get denied the chips I need, plus I'm falling behind in getting resources. but if I collect the resources first, the card I'm saving for might get taken before I get to it. For some reason, I just don't enjoy that form of "damned if you do, damned if you don't" dilemma in games. 

I guess the BGG-voted weight of 1.8 is reasonable. It's simpler than that rules-wise, but has more depth.

RATING: 9
Splendor is a well-balanced, approachable game for new and old players alike. What I especially like about this game is that it is quite fun whether you have 2, 3 or 4 players. My wife and I love playing 1 vs 1, and yet it is also fun if you have a third wheel or another couple to play with. RATING: 9.3
Fell in love with it, the first time I touched those poker chips. Pure class.

The game itself is exactly what I need to have fun. Plan your moves, watch your gem collection expand, curse your opponents for ruining everything for you (reasonable interaction).

With 2 players the game is faster and has a cut throat feel to it. With 3,4 players there is more room for strategic moves (prefer it that way) but I found that some of the non gamers get easily detracted and maybe a bit bored while waiting for their turn.

The game is extremely easy to teach (no more than 5 minutes) and the theme of the game (although not very strong) is pleasing for everyone.

My brother owns it and I steel think of buying it (probably I won’t but that says a lot).

(Wife's Point of View: Bored to death.

...My brother's girlfriend likes it a lot though)

*Update: Bought my own copy, threw the box away and keep everything in a deck tower for portability reasons. ...my brother and his girlfriend went separate ways! This is a take-away game. Get rid of the box.

RATING: 7.5
This is a great entry game for non gamers but also works well with gamers. The rules are simple but there is enough strategy that everyone can enjoy it. It plays in about 40 minutes where you collect coins to buy cards, but the cards you buy also count as coins so you must build up your engine. However you must be sure not to lose sight of the goal and gather points faster then your opponents. You can also block them by taking the coins they want and reserving cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A solid filler. Pure engine building that has a very important timing aspect, knowing when to switch from building your engine to start collecting the big point cards. The first few games I played off this I misjudged the timing and did not score very well, now I’m a bit more experienced I find myself much more competitive. You need to start collecting the big points much earlier than I first suspected, however now I find that I am susceptible to going for it too early and end up struggling to collect the resources needed to pick up the big points.

The ‘shopping’ aspect of collecting resources really seems to appeal to a large group of gamers. I can see this staying in my collection for some time.

RATING: 7
I have a weird opinion about Splendor: I enjoy playing it, but will basically never suggest it.  It's such a pure engine-building game that when it goes off the rails I feel like there's nothing I can do to stop it, which can make the act of playing it feel very frustrating.  I respect the hell out of it, but I'm not always in the mood for that purity of design.

The randomness of the rows can also sometimes be a huge detriment, in that they stymie reasonable attempts to build towards nobles, and punish players who actually attempt to clear cards from the rows. I like to call this the "Ascension" design flaw, and it's weird to see it in what is otherwise such a tight design.

RATING: 6
Splendor is an engine-building filler, where you collect and spend gems to buy cards that make buying future cards cheaper.  As the game progresses you'll be able to afford more expensive cards, which aren't any better than the cheap cards in-game, but do provide more points.  You can also claim goal tiles if you're the first one to collect a certain assortment of cards.  All the cards to be claimed are public, so sniping is possible, but you can see what everyone is doing, so there's not much surprise.  I don't think I've played a filler that feels like this before, so it gets points for originality, but it still only has a filler's amount of depth.

(5+ plays)

RATING: 5
[c]Rules Complexity:.....:halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth:......:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Luck Factor:..........:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime:...:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness:...........:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability:........:star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality:....:star::star::star::star::nostar:
Player Interaction:...:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Theme Integration:....:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:[/c]

Playtime: ~30 minutes

Comment: Turns are incredibly quick once you get your bearings. It's not a deep game, but a very tactical one although you do have to plan ahead. The games pieces are some of the best I've seen. Now if they only went with linen cards... Beautiful artwork on all the cards but unfortunately the theme is rather thin. Clicking the poker chips together does give you that merchant feeling as if you had a handful of gold coins.

Splendor is what I wanted Jaipur to be. Simple, yet entertaining decisions throughout. Jaipur failed on the interesting decisions part.

Optimal Player Count: 3 > 2 > 4

Extras: Cards are sleeved in FFG silver sleeves. I had to cut the insert and turn the cards sideways to fit properly. I just didn't want to throw away the insert since it's quite nice.

The rules for this game are pretty simple, and all the information is public.  Gameplay goes around in circles, and most turns you get to take a card.

I had a lot of fun the two times I played this, but I suspect that may just be because I won.  I worry that replay value might be low as (1) everyone figures out the optimal strategy for the game and (2) people bog down in analysis-paralysis trying to predict which of their moves would have the least convenient consequences for their opponents.

RATING: 8
It took me quite a few plays to figure out where the game is, but there's a lot more going on in this game than might appear when you first try it.  The key to the game is balancing investment (in the form of purchasing no-point cards for future return) vs. simply saving up to buy points.  The calculation will be different each time, and may change based on the actions of other players.  Finding this game more enjoyable over time and not less, which is a surprise.  Bumping the rating up to 8.

RATING: 9
Straight up engine building filler game goodness.

This game benefits from being played often against the same person. When you get to know how your opponent thinks and you become familiar with the game & cards & strategy, there's a bit of a boxing / fencing vibe as you jockey back and forth for scarce resources to build a balanced hand that can win you the royals and then catapult you into a position to buy higher value cards and cross the finish line first. Such a smooth mechanic. Tough decisions beginning to end and very seldom does the deck favor one opponent over the other in a way that can't be overcome by good strategy. They must have play-tested it a lot before releasing it as this game plays like a Swiss watch and the component quality is first class and so is the artwork. 

Downsides / Caveats: Well, the theme is of secondary importance, though it is a nice theme and the artwork is beautiful. The box is big for what the game is. I put the game in a reproduction medieval coin-purse which not only looks cool but now the game travels well in a suitcase / purse / backpack.

RATING: 4
This is an odd one, because the simplicity of this game is exactly what I often claim to like. But unfortunately, in practice I found it deadly dull. Like Port Royal, it's a basic engine-builder with players racing to a VP target, but here it's stripped down to the bare minimum, with each card just providing a discount on one colour towards future purchases. And while the push-your-luck acquisition mechanic in Port Royal provides lots of laughs, the atmosphere in Splendor is more one of silent calculation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fast & light. Fun although far from 'addicting' as others have claimed. A clear strategy is needed to avoid just being 1 or 2 turns short of your own victory when the game ends. I think 15 VP is too little; extending the game to 20-25 VP would mitigate the 'luck-of-the-draw' for the highest point cards (that may never change before the final round). 

The 'claiming' of cards adds a small amount of nastiness that may be misplaced in such a light game (more experienced gamers will more easily see what others need for their strategy), as there is no penalty (other than a lost turn) in keeping cards out of play at the end of the game. I believe that any card held at the end of the game should cost 1 VP each, or better yet, no cards can be held in order to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
You slowly accrue gems to buy cards which become permanent gems, and once you have enough permanent gems you can buy patricians, who simply give victory points, and whoever gets to 15 victory points typically is the winner (other players still get one more turn).

So, my takeaway was frankly the game wasn't nearly as bad as I thought it would be. It's very much a Euro, it plays fairly quick, and it just lacks any real meat. I felt like if maybe the patricians were then used to do something, as an additional layer to the game, it'd be REALLY good, but without that, it feels like it's missing a piece. The quality of the gem chips is very nice, some sort of ceramic-acrylic mix I'd bet, and that certainly adds some quality to the game, but overall a very underwhelming experience. I don't think it deserves any of the praise it's received. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple build your engine filler. Early game is used to collect chips to obtain cards to make buying future cards easier. Later you will be able to afford more expensive cards which also provides victory points. The first to collect certain assortments of cards will be able to claim Nobles (goal cards), which also provides points. 

All cards are public so you can see what others are doing, and can revise your optimization accordingly. It is a filler so there is little depth but it does play quickly. 

Like the chip components and I've not see this twist before so it get a point for originality. Also gets a point since my wife really likes it.

RATING: 5

I may play this again but overall the game got stale fairly quickly and does not have a lot of longevity or depth.

RATING: 5.5
(I've only played a single 2-player game of Splendor so far. This is just my notes-to-self)

= 2015-06-04

Almost a year later and I've only played the game twice now. Just wasn't that exciting. Putting it on the trade pile.

= 2014-05-22

I picked up Splendor because it was described as having "Fired" Jaipur. In some ways, however, it's the opposite of Jaipur. In Splendor, you're building up a points engine. The precious gems you collect are used to collect cards which then reduce the price of future card purchases. The game ramps up from multiple turns per victory point to multiple victory points per turn fairly quickly.

In Jaipur, you're taking cards to collect precious commodities. The most valuable scoring tokens are available early in the game and towards the end you're either fighting for one last high scoring bonus token or going back and forth on a few low scoring turns trying to end the game while you're ahead. Jaipur has a rather significant push-your-luck component. You might chose (or almost be forced) to take a large number of camel cards all at once and then have to draw a bunch of new cards for your opponent to chose from. Jaipur allows for a better calculation of risk. For each type of item (gold, diamonds, leather, etc), there is one more card than there are scoring tokens. If there's only one gold scoring token left, then there are two gold cards left. Do you risk letting your opponent take the 2nd to last gold card so you can focus on building up five leather cards? Is the "Most Camels" bonus worth the risk of turning up good cards for your opponent? Jaipur feels very interactive and it allows just enough calucation to feel like skill played a part in your win.

I haven't figured out Splendor yet. There's no penalty for reserving a card so if you're both (2 player game) getting close to earning a particular card, there's not a ton of risk in just grabbing it.

Once you collect your tokens in Jaipur, you're done with them. There's no reason to ever look back at the things you've earned (except to add up points at the end). In Splendor, you're constantly counting up how many of each token (real and virtual) the other player(s) has and evaluating that against the cards and nobles currently on the table.

Jaipur ends when three piles are exhausted and then the person with the most points wins. Splendor ends when someone gets to a certain number of points so the end game condition is also the win condition (I can't remember for certain, but I think the game continues until everyone has had the same number of turns).

We've only played one 2p game of Splendor, but I think I'll disagree at this point that it fired Jaipur if only because I don't think the games really scratch a similar itch.

Incidentally, I've seen a few people comment on how spectacular the components are in this game. It's true that the poker chips feel good and certainly give the game some heft but wouldn't little acrylic gems have been more thematic and cost less? If ever there was a game that would have benefited from oodles of shiny plastic gems, this is it.

RATING: 7.5
Splendor is a game that I won't veto if asked to play, but it doesn't really "do it" for me.

On the plus side, the components are well done.  I love the poker chip feel and heft.  They are fun to play with on their own..... Don't look at me like that - that's not weird and I doting cause a distraction at the table :).  The cars are just a tiny bit flimsy for my taste, but they are fine for the amount you use them.  I like that the game time is pretty quick, so the game doesn't over stay it's welcome so to speak.  Lastly I like simplicity of the rules - they are easy to teach to newbies.

On the minus side, the noble goals seem "off" to me.  They are tough to get, but only worth three points.  Even with a lot of overlap of card desires, I would think it would be pretty tough to obtain multiple nobles and still win the game.  Also, some of the card costs don't seem balanced to me.  I'll be the first to admit that maybe it's me that's at fault here.  I don't claim to be a veteran player of Splendor so maybe I don't understand the reasons behind some of the choices.  That being said, some cards just seem pretty much all around better to me - you get the same effect for an easier to get combo of tiles in my opinion.  Again, maybe that's by design and there's something I'm. Not seeing, but it bugs me currently.

Description: Abstract, family, tableau building, open drafting, set collection, gem management game.
Number of players: 2 to 4. Best with 4.

Impression: Light, family game about buying cards and collecting gem sets from cheapest to the most expensive until the first player reaches 15 points. There is decent amount of strategy and math involved. It has very nice components, but placed in a box too large for what it is, which is purely for marketing purpose. Apart from that it is a nice filler strategy game.

Likes: Multiple viable strategies. Component quality (heavy gem chips). Quick game play.

Dislikes: First player gets a slight advantage because of the bonus tiles..
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
There are some clever mechanisms in this game. The problem is that, once you've learned the general strategy, it becomes little more than arduous math and luck. You will constantly be adding-up everyone's pieces to calculate their available moves, which is necessary in order to decide your own moves. Constantly.

Sure, you can try using less math and more 'gut instinct'. But then I'll beat you every time unless my card draws are unlucky.

It's a shame because the game has some great aspects. For such a small game, there are plenty of choices and different paths to victory.

RATING: 7
A simple short game. Twelve cards are available for purchase. They each have a cost in gems and each provides a discount of one gem (of a particular type) on subsequent turns as well as victory points. Players can purchase or they can acquire gems to spend on future purchases (three of different colours, two of the same, one wild). The first player to reach fifteen points wins. Its very simple, plays quickly and the game has nice components, chunky poker style chips for the gems and some very nice art on the cards.

RATING: 7
I'm really not sure what the fuss is about with this game. Don't get me wrong, it's a good game - I rated it a 6 after my first play, but upped it to a 7 after my second, seeing a bit more strategy to it that time. And we've played it fairly frequently since then. But, while I'm usually happy to play it, I don't think I'd ever request to do so. There is nothing at all original, it's just an economic snowball-type game of collecting gems to buy cards which give you more gems... 

This is a primarily tactical game, which is quick but with plenty of decisions, and which will play at least a little differently each time. Yet it feels like there's nothing here that hasn't been done before.

It's a good game, very playable - but also quite forgettable as modern releases go. I am puzzled by all the acclaim it seems to have received. (Yet at the same time I enjoy playing it, which of course is ultimately what matters.)

I realise that this is a very confusing, even schizophrenic, kind of judgement on the game - but that's genuinely how I feel. I see almost nothing here to really like - and yet I do enjoy playing it.

RATING: 10
I've only played 3 games of this so far, but my wife and I enjoyed it so much it seemed worth giving it the 10 out of 10. Each turn you take gems (the currency of the game), buy a development card, or reserve a development card. Most of the development cards have a point value, and they also help you buy more development cards. Whomever accumulates 15 points first winds. (There are more details, but that's the gist of it). For such a simple premise, it is surprisingly engaging, and even though you only do one thing per turn, there are many factors to consider in making those decisions. So it's easy to get going and start doing things, but takes a good amount of thought to figure out how to play optimally.

If you're given the chance, definitely play a demo or check it out at your local game store if they do rentals. When a store clerk explained it to me, I wasn't necessarily sold on it. But the cards and the "gems" (plastic coins, really) are really well made. The gems have a poker chip like quality to them that's very satisfying. A game isn't all about the physical components, of course, but the easy to learn/difficult to master nature of the game, combined with the build quality make it a really satisfying game to own and play.

RATING: 6
This game has elements that I love (like resource gathering) but really lacks player interaction. The only way you really interact with other players is to see what gems they have - then aim to take something that you knew they probably wanted. It's funny how silent games of Splendor are - there is very little game related to talk about beyond "oooh, i wanted that". Mechanics of the game are simple enough and a new player will have no problem getting stuck in after only a little explanation time.

The other thing is that three of the gem types are very similar colours for colour-blind people. While I can get around this issue by focusing on the shapes of the gems - it's either a bit of an oversight by the game developers, or the usual "we don't care about 10% of people being colour blind". My girlfriend took our set and marked every single card/piece to make the game easier for me to recognise the different gems and play.

While it is a reasonable game, mechanics wise. I'm afraid that the lack of player interaction means it would never be a go-to game for me or one I'd ever suggest playing, though I could be talked into playing if someone else really wanted to play it.

RATING: 6
There are some tactically interesting plays, and a little bit of strategic planning.  It was a clean and pleasing game, but ultimately pretty forgettable.  My biggest complain is that it didn't feel like there was any interaction -- the other players were just pseudo-random number generators affecting my solitaire game.  I could spend a lot of time figuring out the details of their positions in order to gain a small advantage, but that doesn't seem interesting.  Also, there is a lot of luck in what gets flipped up just before your turn -- that may average out, but it is frustrating and unsatisfying.

update: on more plays, I find the nobles to be problematic -- they over-reward infrastructure and undermine the strategic planning of aiming for high up cards.  Especially in 2p, they seem to create a dominant strategy which in turn becomes a lot about luck of the draw.

RATING: 9
one of the wife's favorite games. 2-player is a great match of wits with clear symbology, a digestible market, open information (mostly), multiple viable avenues for victory, and a not unbearable burden of luck that keeps things fresh. plenty of moderate blocking exists, but can easily cap out and put you slightly behind if you're obnoxious. Nobles are a fun lure to encourage churn of the cheap cards or to bait out a block. 4- and 5-player is more chaotic, but becomes a press-your-luck to find a strategy that isn't overly telegraphed and/or isn't shared by another player. the fact that you CAN have a strategy in an otherwise tactical game is one of my favorite things. wonderful gateway game.

RATING: 7
09-04-2015. Rated after 1 play. Wow, I took a long time trying to play Splendor. And now I've played it, I really like it too.

Basically, Splendor is a race. You try to buy cards, in order to get up to 15 VPs ASAP. There are always 12 open cards, 4 easy, 4 intermediate and 4 difficult (ie. expensive) ones. There are 2 basic ways to score those VPs. You can get them on the cards you buy, and you can get them from having a certain number of cards of colors depending on the tiles that are out there. There are 5 colors (blue, red, white, black, green) and yellow (wild) of resources and cards, and each bought card gives you a subsequent discount based on the jewel in the top corner. 

During your turn, you can take 3 chips of any 3 different colors, except yellow. Or you can take 2 chips of a single color if there are 4 minimum present. You can also take a yellow (wild) chip, and reserve a card you want to buy later. Reserving is possible from the of the deck, or from the display.

I like it. There is not much to it, but it's fun.

RATING: 8.3
Players take on the role of gem merchants, using cards to build up mines, caravans and commerce for points. You will feel the tension and excitement when you play since it's basically a race to 15 points. Simple yet thrilling especially when your opponent leaves you that one card you need to pull off a great move. Games are usually about 10-15 minutes long so we play a best of three or best of five. I highly recommend everyone adding this game to their collection. Ours gets played a lot.

RATING: 5
I don't know what the hype is all about.  There's really nothing innovative here at all, and the total lack of theme means it is not a good family game for my family (like Kingdom Builder, which I also don't understand the interest as a family game).  The lack of player interaction apart from taking/building a card a player wants before they can get means there's no table talk. The chips are really nice, but that's all it's got going for it.  For some reason, I kept wanting to play Augustus instead, which has a similar set collection/race to get scoring tiles, but with a much more innovative, interactive approach.

RATING: 8
Quick to teach and play. A shallow game, but quite fun. Best family game of 2014. My middle daughter is a WBC Juniors champ. :)

UPDATE: I guess the "degenerate" strategy of only going after high-value cards does hurt the game. The designers surely meant this to be an engine-building race game. I'm rather good at the degenerate strategy. But I recognize that it kills the fun of those around me (particularly the fun of some of my kids, who initially really loved the game!) and so that is sad. :(

I wonder if there is a clever way to nerf this approach without harming what is a brilliant design. I don't know that even making the Nobles worth 6 points instead of 3 would make a big difference in many of the games I'm in lately!

RATING: 6
[color=#CC0000]

The beauty of Splendor is that you can play it at a funeral or viewing without disturbing anyone.  You sit very still, not saying a word, occasionally moving a card or turning in a tile on your turn.  Make sure you're not sitting next to the casket, lest other guests confuse you for the deceased.

I keep my copy with my charcoal suit and white shirt, part of my always-ready-rapid-deployment kit for being somber on short notice.

RATING: 8
Edit: Went up from a 7 to an 8.

At first I was afraid that the game gets dull after a couple of plays, but that has not been the case. The games are short enough (only played it 2 players) and the ever changing tableau forces you to adapt your strategy from game to game. The last game played for example, required a lot of white gems, but the tableau did not provide any white gems until two thirds into the game. It was very interesting to see how both players reacted to that situation.

Edit: played it 8 more times. Still enjoy every game. I attribute this to the fact, that the game is a well designed abstract. You love them or you hate them, but they never get old (feel the same about Hive and Qwirkle)

RATING: 5
Not my style of game at all. (I prefer heavier, meatier fare). But if my group feels like they have to fill 30 minutes with a game, this is one of the few that would get my vote.

Really simple rules. Easy for anyone to get into right away. Has a nice easy feel to it. Deck memorization would help your strategy a lot, if you're into that sort of thing. Purely abstract. No theme whatsoever. Illustration is well done but unnecessary and distracting. It's odd that the counters are so overproduced (Bakelite?) while the cards seem so cheap.

RATING: 8.25
This is an easy to teach, fast-paced, exceptionally fun game that works as well for 2 as it does for 4 players. It's a great intro game for new gamers, yet has enough strategy and replayability to keep sophisticated gamers engaged. As others have pointed out the game components are quite high quality especially the heavy weight poker chip style gem tokens. Nonetheless I prefer to play my custom version with upgraded acrylic gems in the correct colors with gold coins replacing the wild tokens. This adds realism to the already fun and well illustrated jeweler theme. I've also added metal Brass coins from Eagle Gryphon Games in 1 and 5 denominations to use as scoring tokens to more easily keep track of everyone's score on the way to 15 prestige points. It makes it much easier to glance over at your opponents coins as opposed to counting card points every turn. Finally, I added the Spendor play mat to provide a logical place for all the cards and nobles, looks great and keeps the cards from sliding around on the tabletop. It's a great stand alone game you can easily complete in 20 mins, but I'd love so see some expansions for Splendor to further augment strategic options. Who's to say the noble that comes to visit your shop couldn't be enticed over to the jeweler across the street who just acquired better gems?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Oh my, how this game depressed me. Somewhere in the middle I looked at my tableau, plateau thingy and went "whee, I'm snowballing". What joy.

So, firstly, there's no game in here, it's just a puzzle exercise. Secondly the game plays itself. Thirdly no theme, no dramaturgy (apart from whee snowballing), they didn't even try getting some theme that would make sense. Fourthly the graphics are terribly uninspired - like somebody just drew over photographs.

About Knizian adjective this game gets and undeservedly so. Yes, the game is simple and the tension is there, similar to Knizia's games. But there's no psychology, no tension arriving from the players, no shared space, it's a MPS. Tension is there, but what kind of tension? It's a tension you get from withdrawal symptom. Your engine is snowballing and you want just more and more and one more gem and one more card, and why did you take that, it's mine, mine, mine, precious! A friend (Martin) made a really clever comparison to game apps played on phones and tablets and such which makes sense both in what this game is and why is it liked. The tension of the game doesn't come from tense choices or risk taking, it comes from addiction. And addiction is not social, there's no common space players share here, it's just junkies grabbing their fix (I apologize if the metaphor offends anyone, it's just one that comes to mind). There's no narrative, nothing. You grab cards, more cards, more more more more and someone wins. 

t felt to me like somebody took your average MPS engine buiding euro and streamlined it by cutting off anything remotely interesting. It even feels to me like a prototype, something than would need to be properly developed. It also feels like a counterattack of engine builders against microgames - if microgames were a revolt against gaming becoming antisocial and too complicated for it's own good, Splendour is where The Empire Strikes Back. It's simple, it's micro, it's as antisocial as it gets. Of course, I do understand people liking it - if you're a gamer, like engine building games, don't care about theme or socialisation, then this is your filler. I'm totally down with that. I would just advise causal gamers to stay the hell away. 

I must say I was immensely relived when Camel Up won SdJ. 

EDIT: Lowered from 2.0 (won't play) to 1.5 (I hope nobody makes such games again)
EDIT 2 - I moved all "I hope nobody makes such games agaim" into 1.0. Hey it's the worst subjective rating I can give.

RATING: 5
Splendor takes an old-school Euro design approach (with more than a passing resemblance to [thing=9217][/thing]) and strips the gameplay down to its barest mechanisms. The engine here is simple – gems will get you cards, which in turn provide more gems to buy more cards.

However, many subtleties and nuances seem to have been lost in midst of streamlining the gameplay. Decisions here are procedural as players routinely count their number of gems, compare them to the costs of cards in the market and take the necessary gems. Sure, players have to keep an eye out for what their opponents are building up towards, but there are very limited opportunities for clever play here.

Other minor drawbacks include the potential for minor downtime as the number of purchasable cards increase towards the midgame, and luck of the draw can allow cards to fall straight into players' laps. Splendor is a solid design overall, but its calculative gameplay simply lacks verve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
2-4 players

I love this game. Would recommend it to anyone really. It's so simple--can teach it in less than 5 minutes. It's a great puzzle. There's no in-your-face player conflict, but will usually elicit at least one or two "screw yous" throughout the course of a game. 

My one complaint is that, thanks to its simplicity, there's no real catch-up mechanism. There's a good amount of room for error in the early game, and some options on some turns are just plain bad. It's short enough where it's not overly frustrating to lose, but you can be left out of the running with no hope of catching up at maybe the half-way point in the game.

Plays: 20+

RATING: 6.5
2 plays.

This is a fun little filler with some gem-related theme pasted on. Basically, though, it's a game of set collection where you're racing to score 15 VP to trigger the end of the game (equal turns) and likely win the game. 

The 3 decks of cards have gems with various costs in other gems. On your turn, either collect poker chips (3 different ones, or 2 of one color as long as you leave at least 2 behind) or claim a card from the display by paying it's cost in gems. Cards you collect remain face up in your display, and act as discounts (essentially, virtual poker chips). OR, you can reserve a card from the display, adding it to your hand and taking one gold chip (acts as a wild color chip). At the start of the game, several bonus tiles were randomly selected; these show particular card combinations. At the end of your turn, if you have any of these combos, you may claim 1 tile. These tiles, and many of the cards, are worth VP; if anyone gets to 15+ VP, finish the current round (even turns): the player with the most VP wins.

It's kind of a cool little game that plays quickly (30-45 minutes) and has some decisions to make without taxing your brain too much. You have to pay attention to what other people are collecting towards, so you can snake those cards/tiles away from them!

RATING: 6
This is an extremely simple and quick filler.  At the start of the game there are 3 rows of gems of increasing cost.  Some give you points (more at higher cost) and they all give you gem production.  Each turn a player selects three different colored gems (or 2 of one color if none are claimed yet), stores a card to be built later and acquires a wild gem, or pays the cost to build a card.  There are also goal tiles worth 3 points each that are acquired when a player builds a certain number of cards of specific gem colors.  This continues until one player gets 15+ points, then the other player gets one final turn to match or beat that score.

For what it is, this game's simplicity doesn't bother me.  It is easy to teach to almost anyone, plays quickly, and is somewhat intriguing.  What really hurts it for me though is the extreme amount of luck that can just ruin a play for someone.  When a card is bought another is flipped over immediately and after the first couple turns those may be automatically acquired by a player if it flips over at the start of their turn.  This way one player may never see the gems they need while the other acquires all the ones they do potentially for free.  I've played this game twice and this happened to me both times, once to an extremely bad degree as each row of 4 cards had 3 of one particular unneeded gem color in them and my opponent constantly got the needed missing colors at the start of his turn free of charge.

If it weren't for that this would be an extremely charming and easy filler.  But I just can't abide being beat by luck every time no matter how well I play.  I wouldn't get much enjoyment out of winning that way either.  The poker chips that come in the game are nice though.

RATING: 7.25
Get rich or die getting slightly less rich!  I think Splendor's mechanics are top notch - letting your opponent take a few turns saving up chips for a card and then nabbing the card under their nose is a great feeling.  There's also enough randomness to make it possible to recover from a few bad investments - squirreling away mines for a gem that isn't well represented NOW might come in handy later when that gem is in high demand. RATING: 6
Splendor is a game that came out of nowhere and all of a sudden took the world of board gaming by storm, and for a while, many was certain it would even win the Spiel des Jahres (it didn't). In this game, players are competing to build the most efficient gemstone output. This is done by acquiring gemstones from a common pool (which thematically makes no sense at all) and using these to acquire mines, gemstone experts and other vital elements of the gemstone industry. As the game is both fast paced and stupendously easy to teach, it is a fine filler game. In by itself, however, it is nothing more than a mediocre card game.

RATING: 8
Very nice set collection game. The rules are so simple than it leaves one wondering why this hasn't been done before.

The game is so straightforward that I may enjoy the game more than it actually deserves. But although the rules are dead easy, deciding what to do is hardly ever simple. The game constantly seduces you to pick the cheap cards, but at one point you should defenitely skip a few turns to save for the big points. You're constantly reminded that turns are a resource just as the jewels are.

All that, and it's great with two. This will get ten plays in no-time.

RATING: 8
Huh.  Maybe I should give more credit to the board game popularity awards, 'cause this is actually a really good little game.  This is basically the most stripped-down version of an "economic engine building" game that one could possibly create, yet it works (it works really well, in fact!).  And though it is a simple game, it moves along at a good clip and doesn't overstay its welcome.  The physical components are top notch: besides the obviously satisfying chunky chips, all the cards are lavishly illustrated, helping the players to remember what the completely unimportant theme of the game is.  The game box should have been much smaller, but that's the only real complaint I can drum up.  So I will just say that this is a splendidly fun and clever game, and leave off with that groaner.  Game design: 4.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 3.5/5  Total: 8/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Elegant abstract filler distills engine-building to its basest level: on a turn, collect gem tokens or spend gem tokens to purchase a gem card. Each gem card you have counts as a gem token of that type for future purchases, so players' buying power rapidly ramps up. Expensive cards are also worth points; first to 15 wins.

A very smooth, elegant design, not too heavy but with some thought required. Quite a bit of randomness: it is frustrating seeing useful, cheap cards turn up right before another player's turn.

RATING: 7
I'm appreciating Splendor more in hindsight.  The game starts at the granular level.  You start picking up chips in different colors, value 1 each, to be used for buying cards.  Cards come out from shuffled decks into a public array, each one a little contract to fulfill -- maybe 3 reds and a white to get a cheap card, but something like 7 blues and 3 blacks to get a card worth 4 or 5 victory points.  Credit alert, though, because even the cheapest cards count as value 1 of a particular color, for unlimited reuse on all further buys!  So you start with the cheapest cards to improve your buying power, but the game is really pretty short so you don't want to wait too long to transition to buying the cards worth VP.  The flow is very smooth and I believe the game will repay repeated play.

RATING: 9
This is the heaviest played game in our house.   Everyone loves it.   I love it.   One of my favorite games ever.   It strikes a balance few games have.

It plays quickly, is easy to explain the rules, and is just a FUN game from there on.

This has been updated to be my favorite game from a point of YOU ARE IN CONTROL OF YOUR FATE in the game.... no dice, just your tactics, win and it is very satisfying!  Lose and it's really your own fault! 

Ignore the reviews that say one strategy wins you the game, it's not true.   There are plenty of ways to win.  

It has a balance I have not really seen in games, a major hit for us, couldn't be more happy.   Hope they make expansions!   The only reason I'll ding it a bit is the cards themselves are pretty cheap stock, definately need sleeves. Compared to the chips which I'll comment on below.

Another thing, this game comes with the best organizer insert of any game I've personally purchased.   Everything has its place and the "Gem... Poker Chips" are made of some very heavy plastic stock as in Casinos.   

Buy it you won't regret it.

UPDATE: The only flaw I found in the well designed organizer is that once the cards are sleeved they don't fit well at all any longer.

RATING: N/A

RATING: 6
What a great game. Very simple to play and I can see this leading the next generation of gateway games.

The feel of the game reminds me of Saint Petersberg: on your turn you can buy a card from a face-up selection of cards, take a card into your hand to play later, or collect gems (which are used to buy more cards). The cards you buy will accumulate and make it cheaper for you to buy other cards in the future.

On top of the simplicity, a game takes maybe 30 minutes, putting this into super-filler territory. There's a good amount of things to think about, though, and there's just enough player interaction though indirect. The player interaction is in the form of deciding which cards to take (to deny your opponents), taking gems that your opponents could possibly use (the gem supply is limited), and a race to collect certain cards to get a bonus in the form of nobles. You usually have a few different options each turn, so being blocked in one area isn't devastating like it is in some games. Euro gamers should appreciate this sort of indirect interaction.

My only complaint is the amount of luck in the game. A player can get lucky when someone buys a card then the new card that comes out is one that can be bought immediately by someone else who happens to have the right cards/gems in front of them. This can even decide the game in the final rounds.
For example, I was the start player in a game and, near the end of the game, on my turn I could see that based on the available cards nobody would be able to buy any of more valuable cards. So I reserved a four-point card, planning to play it in the next round to put me over 15 points. But the replacement card that came out was another four-point card that matched up perfectly with the gems that the next player already had. That player bought the card, got more than 15 points, and won the game.

Extremely elegant and a lot of fun, although a bit luck-based.

Sold.

RATING: 9
This is one of my personal favorites. Marc Andre captures a mechanic, makes it as clean and simple as possible and turns it into a great game with high quality components.

Take coins (gems), spend them on cards that grant you more gems, and use your new bank of gems to purchase high level cards and eventually obtain enough victory points to win the game.

If you enjoy resource managment and card driven gameplay, this is a must have. Ive played this with up to 4 players and it scales beautifully. A must own for any collection!

Splendor isn't a game that I knew anything about specifically, other than that it was a light, quick game that "didn't really do much new". And that's all true. But I like this game.
