=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[thing=148228][/thing] is a light set collection type of game. In your turn you have a small set of options:
- take two chips of the same color (if there are at least 4 chips in the stack);
- take 3 chips, all of different colors;
- take one card from the rows and one gold chip (maximum of three cards separated - you must always pay the cost of these cards, you can't just put them back in the rows);
- pay the cost of one card and put it in front of you.

The cards are divided in three rows, accordingly to the amount of chips necessarry to build them. The less chips, the easier to pay its costs. Every card will have the kind of chips necessary to pay for it, and also will have a type of precious stone - once you take it, the cost of that type of color will reduce in one. So, for example, if the card you took has 1 green gem on it, the next time you will pay for some card that needs green, you will pay one less (up to zero).

Some of the cards are worth victory points, and also there are nobles, which are worth 3 points and require a set of colors to "visit" the first player that complete the set. The game ends when someone reaches 15 points, when this happen, the players will finish the round of play so that everyone has had the same number of turns. The winner will be the player with the most points.

As one can see, [thing=148228][/thing] is a game that can be explained in few minutes and played by anyone that grasped games like [thing=9209][/thing], beign as light as this one. And it plays even faster: usually you will have your turn figure out way before the game returns to you. When we played, one AP player was always surprise to see that the play had already returned to him. Even with this, we played the whole game in around 40 minutes. I won't be surprise at all if the plays, once everyone has the flow of the game set in, will last around only 30 minutes.

It is an easy going game, with some indirect confrontation (I can take a card I see you want to take, or I can hold chips of one color in order to prevent, for some time, other to build cards of that color), nothing major, so, even if you play with family or players that dislike confront, they will probably still enjoy [thing=148228][/thing].

The game has some luck in its play: for instance, if you take several cards that lower the cost one, say white (diamonds) cards, and the ones that are worth points requiring a high number of white don't show up, well... So it is best, as far as I can see, the spread your options, taking, at least in the beginning, cards of almost every color, in order to be somewhat prepare for everything that shows up later. Even with luck, usually the player that played the best will win - something that is always great.

As it was said many time, [thing=148228][/thing] has some [b]awesome[/b] chips - they are sturdy, heavy - a friend of mine thought they were made of metal (but no). Yes, the box is huge for what comes inside, but everything stay in its place, the cards fit even when sleeved (a major plus for me) - so I can't complain about the box. The cards are OK and the noble tiles are thick. Overall, an excellent production value - it makes well worth the price of it (which isn't cheap, considering the game doesn't came with a big lot of components).

So, [thing=148228][/thing] has proven itself as a great option of filler, giving several things to consider in every turn, but none of them overwhelmingly hard nor requiring several minutes of ponderation. It isn't as portable as, say, [thing=172][/thing], nor it accepts as many players as [thing=37759][/thing], but it is a heavier than both, and it will probably be a good choice for players that want more meat in their fillers.

Recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Cities of Splendor
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Good:
-Perfect gateway game
-Elegant game design
-Amazingly simple to explain
-Only one action per turn makes decision making easy
-You get significantly better after multiple plays
-Great components
-Cards are well balanced
-Leaves people wanting more
-Not as luck based as it appears
-Multiple paths to victory

Bad:
-While rare, luck can hand a player the victory
-At times, you wish it was a grander game
-Can run long if everyone is only going after level-1 cards
-Really needs an expansion

Overall:
This is likely the best gateway game on the market.  Almost always a hit and, due to its simple rules, players can quickly into the game without feeling overwhelmed.  After the first few turns, you will start to hear new players have their epiphanies when they start to see the bigger strategy.  This is the perfect litmus to determine if the people you coerced into playing one game with you are interested in playing more strategy games.  The game teeters on being a filler game because of its length but is too deep for that label.  The reserve mechanic allows this game to have significant strategic depth that is often missed by its critics.

Get it. Play it. Share the itchy love.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yes, Splendor is a simple exercise in resource management. You buy A to give you X, You buy B to give you Y, etc. Then use X and Y to buy C. That is it. There aren't even many ways to win prestige points. Just those that are being printed on the resource cards as well as nobles. First player to reach 15 prestige points triggers the last round and the game ends. Most points win. Simple, straightforward, no chrome.

Yet, after a few plays, the game stands out for its simplicity distilled down to the bare essence that is resource management. In a way, I find this refreshing. The resource generation in Splendor is not unlike 7 wonders minus the drafting. But think of 7 wonders and I shudder at explaining all the ways points are accumulated in the game. It is just so much chrome tacked on the basic game play. Splendor is almost the antithesis of 7 wonders. 

Still, this game will find only a smaller audience. Folks who eschew lengthy rules, want a simple game without messy explanations and fast game play. When those folks are around, I shall reach for Splendor and....Caveman Curling.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The perfect mix of balance in what cards cost and different ways to gain significant points from controlling nobles or going for tier 3 cards.  This game never plays out quite the same way and while some "strategies" might appear to be dominant (I have heard players at gaming clubs talking about this) they are absolutely not dominant their opponents just do not know how to adjust to what other players are doing.  I have general tactics for my early game that rarely change very much depending on the options but I never play the end game one specific way "because it is the dominant strategy".  I have an absurd win rate for a game like this by tactically keeping track of everything each player is doing and the mathematical value of all my turn options.  To achieve this win rate I have to constantly be willing to change my planned turn and to not be relying on no one trying to stop my best visible options by reserving a card or two.  Even when everyone at the table is aware I am the biggest threat and try to conspire against me this game rewards careful decision making.  Luck can occasionally dominate an entire game and make a win "nearly impossible" but 80% of games will go to the player who made the best decisions.

RATING: 10
This is an all-around fun game: it has a lot of luck, but just enough strategy to make it interesting, such as wasting a move to reserve a key card at the right time. It's short (20-30 minutes); the cards and chips have a beautiful design and feel to them; and the game is simple and has only a few rules. I'd say it's my very favorite short game, but it's just robust enough to not really be a filler game. The rules can be taught quickly and the game can be mostly understood on the first try playing the game. And it works just as well with only 2 players as it does with 3 or 4, which makes it double as a challenging 2 player game as well, which is rare for multi-player board games.

Official game description: As a wealthy Renaissance merchant, acquire mines and transportation, hire artisans and woo the nobility. Create the most fantastic jewelry to become the best-known merchant of them all! Acquire precious stones to trade them for development cards. Use development cards to acquire more gem stones. Use your gems and gold to create the most fantastic jewelry, and appeal to the nobles to gain the prestige you need to win.

RATING: 8
Oct 2017: 
I have a lot of great things to say about this game.  It is ALWAYS the first game I recommend to someone who wants to get a non-gamer into gaming.  Why?  Because it doesn't feel too much like a gamer's game.  It's not too heavy, it doesn't have any "weird" themes, and the cards don't feel too much different from a normal set of cards.  It's a step beyond Lost Cities, which is still just a card game, but not quite a Ticket to Ride or Carcassonne.  Everyone we've introduced to games with this has enjoyed it and quickly mastered it enough to be competitive.   We, personally, don't play it much if we aren't playing with non-gamers, but I can still recognize that this game is one that belongs in basically every collection.  I also feel like it does shine at 3-4P, while we are usually stuck with only 2P.  (Really hoping to see the expansion make this more replayable for us, though.)

Original, Dec 2016:
Not my favorite game, but is definitely in or near my top 10 list!  This game is perfect in many ways, even if it's not *my* favorite.  What makes it great?

* Rules are quick and easy to learn.  Perfect gateway game that works well even with people who only play "traditional card games".
* Set-up is fast.
* It takes just the right amount of time to play, not dragging on too long or being too short.
* There is a bit of a luck factor (especially coming to turn order sometimes), but it's also "thinky" enough to keep me interested in playing multiple rounds in a row.
* Beautiful artwork.  While the theme doesn't really play across strongly (it just feels like a card game with pretty art), I don't consider that a flaw.  It makes it more appealing to people who are generally against any sort of board game.
* Slightly different each time depending on what nobles you draw and what cards are turned over.  The same strategy doesn't *always* work.

My parents also own this game.

RATING: 5
enjoyable light "filler"-kind game, part engine building and part scoring-race; to me it is very similar to the recent Builders:Middle-Age that offers the same feel, same difficulty level/decision ratio, same playing time in a MUCH smaller box and more attractive theme (that feels less pasted on).

[+] very nice components and box insert, fast paced & short game with a good amount of decisions to make, easy to teach, not easy to master (you have to get the timing right of when to stop building an engine and start scoring)
[-] theme or no theme, that is the question... abrupt end game (Builders:Midddle-Age has that as well), seems weird that the "cost" of similar cards can be very different (a level 1 card with no point value costs between 3 and 5-6 gems, why?)

RATING: 5
The game has a neat idea, but I think it suffers a little bit due to a few mechanisms.  The buying phase of the game is interesting, with the ramp up from being poor to being rich happening swiftly, so it feels like there's a lot of spending, and then the game is over.  It doesn't allow much time for altering plans, but then again, it's so short that it might not be an issue.  I also had problems with the game not penalizing players for reserving cards, since it seemed like it was too easy for players to mess others up just by taking cards.  It's an OK game, and I'd play it if others wanted to, but it doesn't strike me as something special.

RATING: 8
Pure engine building. Every bit as satisfying as Dominion, but with zero card text and barely any rules overhead. As an added bonus, it plays great with 2,3 or 4. Best of all, each of those configurations feels like a totally different game. The four player game is resource rich and more relaxed, while the two player game is a slow grind with tons of hate drafting. While that will force the game into a specific niche for most people, depending on their likes and dislikes, for me it feels like getting three games in one box. For sure, I'd slot this just behind Biblios as the best filler game in my entire collection.

RATING: 7
Splendor is a nice and good game, but at least for me, it has its issues. For one the late game feels way too rushed and automatic (every player just seems to grab whatever he can afford for free and what gives the most points - the amount of decisions is very limited towards the end) and - at least with 2 players - one player can - by luck of the card draw - completly shut the other player out of one of the colors - which makes it nearly impossible for the other player to win. This can be very frustrating as it has nothing to do with skill but just with knwoing about this denial strategy and having the luck of the right cards showing up at the right times.

It plays super fast (10-15min), setup and teardown are minimal and the quality of the components is perfect, but for a really "great" game a bit more emphasizeon skill vs. luck would have been required.

RATING: 8
Players take the role of wealthy Renaissance merchants buying and selling gems to turn into beautiful refined jewels. Splendor is an abstract game of "card drafting" and "engine building".
On your turn you can only perform one of four different actions, each action is a dilemma. Do you buy the mine that you need now, or do you buy the shop that you know your oponent needs, just so he can't get it.
Easy to learn, hard to master.

RATING: 7.4
What I Like-
Grabbing chips, to buy cards, that make future purchases cheaper, to gather victory point cards and entice nobles to visit. Reserving a card for later. Good planning is rewarded. Low to no luck. Plays quick. 

What I Dislike-
Game ends at 15 points regardless of who went first. Cards have no abilities other than providing a gem and/or victory points. Turns are pretty flat in terms of actions and excitement. You either gather chips or purchase a card. No combos or special abilities on the cards makes it rather boring.

RATING: 5
With new games, I don't normally play them four times (kinda sad) in the first month that I own them, but Splendor has that quality that makes you want to play it again and again. There's not too much to this game: you get chips to buy cards which make it easier to buy other cards which eventually have points and having certain configurations of cards allows you to get more points. It's an efficiency engine much like St. Petersburg. However, this one is a lot more interesting for some reason, nice poker chips maybe?. Another benefit to the game is that it plays in about 30 to 45 minutes with all of the player counts and that time will get much faster with repeat plays. I'm looking forward to playing this one a lot more.

RATING: 9
Splendor is a great same that is simple to learn and interesting to play.  It has both tactical and strategic elements to it all in a 30 minute or less game.  It plays well with 2, 3, or 4, though each is a bit different.  

The game has little theme so it can be a bit boring to some that are coming from heavier themed games, but still enjoyable to play.  

The game does have better and worse strategies, though there they don't always win if you the play the better one.  It does still have to do with the luck of the draw and what other people open up to you in terms of options.  That is a small drawback of the game.  The player to your right can influence what options you have available so table positioning can be an issue.  I do suggest randomizing table position as well as start player so that you don't have anyone trying to be next to someone or not next to someone based on their skill level.

Overall, a great, quick game with enough depth to be interesting, but short enough to play multiple times rapidly.

RATING: 9
I absolutely love this game. Easy to teach, accessible to those new to gaming and still interesting for more experienced gamers. 

The theme is completely irrelevant, and it's rather like an abstract strategy card game. Not a game that is high in interaction, and can feel a bit like multi-player solitaire with players that don't actively work to thwart each other. Which makes this a really great game for me to play with my kids when I want a more focused and (somewhat) quiet experience. 

I think this is a really great family game to include even very young players. The game play is not at all complicated, so a 4 yr old could play this easily. My 6 yr old says this is one of her favourite games, and she definitely holds her own against the rest of us.

RATING: 7.25
The first time that I played Splendor I felt that it was just an "OK" game. It was fairly light and quick to play but nothing overly impressive. Time passed by and I saw it shooting up the BGG ranks but didn't think much about it. It wasn't until I started playing more games during my lunch hour and realizing that I didn't have many games that were suitable to fit in that time slot that Splendor came back on my radar. Yes... it was "OK" but, if found at a decent price, I would pick it up.

Well... I'm happy that I did. Yes... it is a simple and quick playing game but it's a lot of fun, looks great and, who doesn't like weighty custom poker chips? The game feels like a tactical deck builder to me, where you're trying to improve your own economic engine while ensuring that your opponents can't maximize theirs. The games generally end up being fairly close and it always seems to be a race at the end. Very fun.

I can comfortably play 1 -2 games in under 60 minutes. Given that this has gone over well at lunch and that my wife enjoys it as well... this could see quite a bit of action.

RATING: 6.1
Splendor is another awesome filler game that will appeal to pretty much everyone. I'm so glad that I have this game because my wife loves it and even though it is a light game I still feel pleased as I'm playing it because you're constantly making choices in the game. I find that I love games that offer you opportunities to make different choices. It may seem on the surface that there aren't many choices in this game but the choices you have can, at times, be nail biting.  That is a rare thing for a filler game. I do feel like the game is slightly deeper than what some let on.  Don't get me wrong, the game is light but it's just so satisfying. Also, this game has complete open information so you can always see what your opponents are doing and what cards they're probably going to be going for. I'm not always a fan of this, but I do enjoy it in lighter games.

Note:  Sleeved with Mayday Premium Card Game Sleeves (green pack) Box insert cut to accommodate sleeved cards.

RATING: 8.7
And suddenly there was Splendor. We were walking around a convention, and noticed a couple of players that were very enthusiastic. A bit too enthusiastic if you would asked me, but it got us curious to this game we’ve never heard of. In one way, that wasn’t strange, because the official release date was March 26, 2014, three days after we walked at the convention. I did some research on the internet, and the game ended on our wishlist. Just three days after it’s official release, we went to a board game store in Essen. And there it was. Brand new, only one copy left, like it was just waiting for us. We grabbed the copy and when we arrived back home, we started playing it. Wow, this game is a little gem. The enthusiasm of the players at the convention was a bit over the top, but on the other hand, not all people express their feelings like we do. We can be very enthusiastic about a game, and nobody would notice it. So, this was such kind of a game. The rules a very easy to understand and explain. Picking up playing the game, will take less then 5 minutes. The end of the game is most of the time very close with two players. Often it only differs one turn in who is winning the game. If we would have to give a point of criticism to this game, then it will be the short playing time. This makes it not suitable as a game. It’s too long for a filler game. It’s too short to give you the feeling that you’ve played a game. And the theme? Well, it’s a Eurogame. It’s pasted on.

RATING: 10
Many people compare Splendor with Sid Sackson's Bazaar.  I own both games and beside the fact that they share the same theme,  they don't have much in common.  Splendor shares more similarities with his big brother St Petersburg.  Their mechanics are similar,  but Splendor is shorter (10-15 minutes per player) and is easier to learn.  It has the potential to appeal to non-gamers like mom and dad... and is still challenging for gamers. The material is gorgeous and handling those heavy tokens is really a pleasure.  Splendor is slowing raising among my top gateway games and deserves a permanent place in my collection.
